Note well the words of Jesus, if you are heavy-laden with your service, and do not mistake it. It is not, Go, labor on, as perhaps you imagine. On the contrary, it is stop, turn back, Come to me and rest. Never, never did Christ send a heavy laden one to work; never, never did He send a hungry one, a weary one, a sick or sorrowing one, away on any service. For such the Bible only says, Come, come, come.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: In Shansi I found Chinese Christians who were accustomed to spend time in fasting and prayer. They recognized that this fasting, which so many dislike, which requires faith in God, since it makes one feel weak and poorly, is really a Divinely appointed means of grace. Perhaps the greatest hindrance to our work is our own imagined strength; and in fasting we learn what poor, weak creatures we are-dependent on a meal of meat for the little strength which we are so apt to lean upon.'
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: Do not work so hard for Christ that you have no strength to pray, for prayer requires strength.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: I have seen many men work without praying, though I have never seen any good come out of it; but I have never seen a man pray without working.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: Whatever is your best time in the day, give that to communion with God.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: As our Father makes many a flower to bloom unseen in the lonely desert, [let us] do all that we can do, as under God's eye, though no other eye ever take note of it.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: I used to ask God to help me. Then I asked if I might help Him. I ended up by asking Him to do His work through me.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: Many Christians estimate difficulties in the light of their own resources, and thus attempt little and often fail in the little they attempt. All God's giants have been weak men who did great things for God because they reckoned on His power and presence with them.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: At the timberline where the storms strike with the most fury, the sturdiest trees are found.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: All our difficulties are only platforms for the manifestations of His grace, power and love.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: The use of means ought not to lessen our faith in God, and our faith in God ought not to hinder our using whatever means He has given us for the accomplishment of His own purposes.
author: Hudson Taylor

quote: If you are affronted it is better to pass it by in silence, or with a jest, though with some dishonor, than to endeavor revenge. If you can keep reason above passion, that and watchfulness will be your best defenders.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: We build too many walls and not enough bridges.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: No sciences are better attested than the religion of the Bible.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: Tact is the art of making a point without making an enemy.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: If I have seen further than others, it is by standing upon the shoulders of giants.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: I was like a boy playing on the sea-shore, and diverting myself now and then finding a smoother pebble or a prettier shell than ordinary, whilst the great ocean of truth lay all undiscovered before me.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: To me there has never been a higher source of earthly honor or distinction than that connected with advances in science.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: If I have made any improvement in the sciences, it is owing more to patient attention than to anything beside.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: If I have done the public any service, it is due to my patient thought.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: We account the Scriptures of God to be the most sublime philosophy. I find more sure marks of authenticity in the Bible than in any profane history whatever.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: A man may imagine things that are false, but he can only understand things that are true, for if the things be false, the apprehension of them is not understanding.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: Errors are not in the art but in the artificers.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: It is the weight, not numbers of experiments that is to be regarded.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: To every action there is always opposed an equal reaction.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: We are to admit no more causes of natural things than such as are both true and sufficient to explain their appearances.
author: Isaac Newton

quote: To be angry about trifles is mean and childish; to rage and be furious is brutish; and to maintain perpetual wrath is akin to the practice and temper of devils; but to prevent and suppress rising resentment is wise and glorious, is manly and divine.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The very substance which last week was grazing in the field, waving in the milk pail, or growing in the garden, is now become part of the man.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: A hermit who has been shut up in his cell in a college has contracted a sort of mould and rust upon his soul.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Some persons believe everything that their kindred, their parents, and their tutors believe. The veneration and the love which they have for their ancestors incline them to swallow down all their opinions at once, without examining what truth or falsehood there is in them. Men take their principles by inheritance, and defend them as they would their estates, because they are born heirs to them.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: As a man may be eating all day, and for want of digestion is never nourished, so these endless readers may cram themselves in vain with intellectual food.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: If a book has no index or good table of contents, it is very useful to make one as you are reading it.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Talking over the things which you have read with your companions fixes them on the mind.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: In common discourse we denominate persons and things according to the major part of their character; he is to be called a wise man who has but few follies.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Satirists do expose their own ill nature.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Learn good-humor, never to oppose without just reason; abate some degree of pride and moroseness.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: When two or three sciences are pursued at the same time if one of them be dry, as logic, let another be more entertaining, to secure the mind from weariness.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The child taught to believe any occurrence a good or evil omen, or any day of the week lucky, hath a wide inroad made upon the soundness of his understanding.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Were both the golden Indies mine, I'd give both Indies for a tear.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Preserve your conscience always soft and sensitive. If but one sin force its way into that tender part of the soul and dwell there, the road is paved for a thousand iniquities.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Among all the accomplishments of youth there is none preferable to a decent and agreeable behavior among men, a modest freedom of speech, a soft and elegant manner of address, a graceful and lovely deportment, a cheerful gravity and good-humor, with a mind appearing ever serene under the ruffling accidents of human life.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Roses grow on thorns and honey wears a sting.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: I would not change my blest estate for all the world calls good or great.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Then let these useless streams be stayed; wear native courage in your face.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Academical disputation gives vigor and briskness to the mind thus exercised, and relieves the languor of private study and meditation.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Instructors should not only be skilful in those sciences which they teach, but have skill in the method of teaching, and patience in the practice.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: When general observations are drawn from so many particulars as to become certain and indisputable, these are jewels of knowledge.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: I believe the promises of God enough to venture an eternity on them.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: In matters of equity between man and man, our Saviour has taught us to put my neighbor in place of myself, and myself in place of my neighbor.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Earth, thou great footstool of our God, who reigns on high; thou fruitful source of all our raiment, life, and food; our house, our parent, and our nurse.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Do not be deceived; happiness and enjoyment do not lie in wicked ways.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Nothing tends so much to enlarge the mind as travelling, that is, making visits to other towns, cities, or countries beside those in which we were born and educated.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: How divinely full of glory and pleasure shall that hour be when all the millions of mankind that have been redeemed by the blood of the Lamb of God shall meet together and stand around Him, with every tongue and every heart full of joy and praise! How astonishing will be the glory and the joy of that day when all the saints shall join together in one common song of gratitude and love, and of everlasting thankfulness to this Redeemer! With that unknown delight, and inexpressible satisfaction, shall all that are saved from the ruins of sin and hell address the Lamb that was slain, and rejoice in His presence!
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Let me be dressed fine as I will, Flies, worms, and flowers, exceed me still.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Satan finds some mischief still for idle hands to do.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Acquaint yourself with your own ignorance.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Fancy and humour, early and constantly indulged in, may expect an old age overrun with follies.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The calmest and serenest hours of life, when the passions of nature are all silent, and the mind enjoys its most perfect composure.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Thou sun, whose beams adorn the spheres, and with unwearied swiftness move to form the circles of our years.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: May I govern my passions with absolute sway, and grow wiser and better as life wears away.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Two sentiments alone suffice for man, were he to live the age of the rocks - love, and the contemplation of the Deity.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: When a false argument puts on the appearance of a true one, then it is properly called a sophism or fallacy.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Affect not little shifts and subterfuges to avoid the force of an argument.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Do not hover always on the surface of things, nor take up suddenly, with mere appearances; but penetrate into the depth of matters, as far as your time and circumstances allow, especially in those things which relate to your profession.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: A dogmatical spirit inclines a man to be censorious of his neighbors. Every one of his opinions appears to him written, as it were, with sunbeams, and he grows angry that his neighbors do not see it in the same light. He is tempted to disdain his correspondents as men of low and dark understandings because they do not believe what he does.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Poesy and oratory omit things not essential, and insert little beautiful digressions, in order to place everything in the most effective light.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Some have a violent and turgid manner of talking and thinking; they are always in extremes, and pronounce concerning everything in the superlative.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Though reading and conversation may furnish us with many ideas of men and things, yet it is our own meditation must form our judgment.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Acquire a government over your ideas, that they may come down when they are called, and depart when they are bidden.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Logic helps us to strip off the outward disguise of things, and to behold and judge of them in their own nature.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Reason is the glory of human nature, and one of the chief eminences whereby we are raised above the beasts, in this lower world.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The eyes of a man in the jaundice make yellow observations on everything; and the soul tinctured with any passion diffuses a false color over the appearance of things.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The passions are the gales of life; and it is religion only that can prevent them from rising into a tempest.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: In Job and the Psalms we shall find more sublime ideas, more elevated language, than in any of the heathen versifiers of Greece or Rome.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Study detains the mind by the perpetual occurrence of something new, which may gratefully strike the imagination.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: The fondness we have for self furnishes another long rank of prejudices.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: For one drop calls another down, till we are drowned in seas of grief.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: I love the soul that dares tread the temptations of his years beneath his youthful feet.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Learning to trust is one of life's most difficult tasks.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Disputation carries away the mind from that calm and sedate temper which is so necessary to contemplate truth.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: It was a saying of the ancients, 'Truth lies in a well;' and to carry on this metaphor, we may justly say that logic does supply us with steps, whereby we may go down to reach the water.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Raillery and wit were never made to answer our inquiries after truth, and to determine a question of rational controversy, though they may be sometimes serviceable to expose to contempt those inconsistent follies which have been first abundantly refuted by argument; they serve indeed only to cover nonsense with shame, when reason has first proved it to be mere nonsense.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: Vice and virtue chiefly imply the relation of our actions to men in this world; sin and holiness rather imply their relation to God and the other world.
author: Isaac Watts

quote: If you feel that you can follow a few little rules or some clever gimmicks to make you a mature Christian, then you have fallen into a subtle trap of legalism.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: There is a brotherhood within the body of believers, and the Lord Jesus Christ is the common denominator. Friendship and fellowship are the legal tender among believers.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: There's a pardon for every sinner on the topside of the earth, but you have to call for it by faith before it becomes yours. In other words, you have to trust Christ as your Savior.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: Faith is not a leap in the dark. Faith is not a 'hope so.' Faith is substance and evidence - substance for a scientific mind, and evidence for a legal mind.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: You can believe a whole lot of foolish things, but God doesn't want you to do that. He wants your faith to rest upon the Word of God.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: When I hear Christians say, 'I don't do this, and I don't do that, and I am following a set of rules,' I immediately recognize that they know very little about the grace of God. They are trying to live the Christian life in their own strength. But Paul says, 'Be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.'
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: Don't say that a loving God is going to send you to hell - He's not. The thing that's going to send you to hell is that you're a sinner and you don't want to admit it.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: In order to live a life of holiness, we must first receive new life from God - we must be born from above.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: If a sinner comes into your assembly or you otherwise come into contact with him, remember that he is a human being for whom Christ died. He stands at the foot of the cross, just as you stand at the foot of the cross.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: When a man and a woman give themselves to each other in an act of marital love, they can know the love of Christ as no one else can know it.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: There are so many people who want to get together to have a great prayer meeting or other great gatherings. Friend, have you ever tried being alone? That is where God will meet with you. Take the Word of God and go off alone with Him. It will do you a lot of good.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: Jesus was not tempted to see if He would fall. He was tempted to show that He could not fall.
author: J. Vernon McGee

quote: The man who has nothing more than a kind of Sunday religion -- whose Christianity is like his Sunday clothes put on once a week, and then laid aside -- such a man cannot, of course, be expected to care about growth in grace.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Tomorrow is the devil's day, but today is God's. Satan does not care how spiritual your intentions are, or how holy your resolutions, if only they are determined to be done tomorrow.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Assurance after all is no more than a full-grown faith; a masculine faith that grasps Christ's promise with both hands - a faith that argues like the good centurion, if the Lord 'speak the word only,' I am healed. Wherefore then should I doubt? (Matt. 8:8).
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Backsliding, generally first begins with neglect of private prayer.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Men fall in private long before they fall in public.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We ought to regard the sacrament of baptism with reverence. An ordinance of which the Lord Jesus Himself partook, is not to be lightly esteemed. An ordinance to which the great Head of the Church submitted, ought to be ever honorable in the eyes of professing Christians.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Amidst the flood of dangerous reading, I plead for my Master's book; I call upon you not to forget the book of the soul. Do not let newspapers, novels, and romances be read, while the prophets and Apostles be despised. Do not let the exciting and sensual swallow up your attention, while the edifying and the sanctifying can find no place in your mind.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Value all books in proportion as they are agreeable to Scripture. Those that are nearest to it are the best, and those that are farthest from it, and most contrary to it, the worst.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The storms of winter often bring out the defects in a man's dwelling, and sickness often exposes the gracelessness of a man's soul. Surely anything that makes us find out the real character of our faith is good.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Beware of letting small faults pass unnoticed under the idea it is a little one. There are no little things in training children; all are important. Little weeds need plucking up as much as any. Leaven them alone and they will soon be great.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Children are very quick observers; very quick in seeing through some kinds of hypocrisy, very quick in finding out what you really think and feel, very quick in adopting all your ways and opinions. You will often discover that, as the father is, so is the son.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Imagination is the hotbed where this sin is too often hatched. Guard your thoughts, and there will be little fear about your actions.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The one true Church is composed of all believers in the Lord Jesus. It is made up of all God's elect - of all converted men and women - of all true Christians. In whomever we can discern the election of God the Father, the sprinkling of the blood of God the Son, the sanctifying work of God the Spirit, in that person we see a member of Christ's true church.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We should no more tolerate false doctrine that we would tolerate sin.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: A good conscience will save no man, wash away no sin, not lift us one hair's breadth towards heaven. Yet a good conscience will be found a pleasant visitor at our bedside in a dying hour.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: I doubt, indeed, whether we have any warrant for saying that a man can possibly be converted without being consecrated to God. More consecrated he doubtless can be, and will be as his grace increases; but if he was not consecrated to God in the very day that he was converted and born again, I do not know what conversion means.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: To be born again is, as it were, to enter upon a new existence, to have a new mind, a new heart, new views, new principles, new tastes, new affections, new likings, new dislikings, new fears, new joys, new sorrows, new love to things once hated, new hatred to things once loved, new thoughts of God, and ourselves, and the world, and the life to come, and salvation.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: There are very few errors and false doctrines of which the beginning may not be traced up to unsound views about the corruption of human nature. Wrong views of the disease will always bring with them wrong views of the remedy. Wrong views of the corruption of human nature will always carry with them wrong views of the grand antidote and cure of that corruption.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: What would you expect? Sin will not come to you, saying, 'I am sin.' It would do little harm if it did. Sin always seems 'good, and pleasant, and desirable,' at the time of commission.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Doctrine is useless if it is not accompanied by a holy life. It is worse than useless; it does positive harm. Something of 'the image of Christ' must be seen and observed by others in our private life, and habits, and character, and doings.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Inability to distinguish doctrine is spreading far and wide, and so long as the preacher is 'clever' and 'earnest,' hundreds seem to think it must be all right, and call you dreadfully 'narrow and uncharitable' if you hint that he is unsound!
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Sound doctrine and holy living are the marks of true prophets. Let us remember this. [A] minister's mistakes will not excuse our own.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Doubting does not prove that a man has no faith, but only that his faith is small. And even when our faith is small, the Lord is ready to help us.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Faith is to the soul what life is to the body. Prayer is to faith what breath is to the body. How a person can live and not breathe is past my comprehension, and how a person can believe and not pray is past my comprehension too.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The faith which has not a sanctifying influence on the character is no better than the faith of devils. It is a 'dead faith, because it is alone.'
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Gradual growth in grace, growth in knowledge, growth in faith, growth in love, growth in holiness, growth in humility, growth in spiritual-mindedness - all this I see clearly taught and urged in Scripture, and clearly exemplified in the lives of many of God's saints. But sudden, instantaneous leaps from conversion to consecration I fail to see in the Bible.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The ways, and fashions, and amusements, and recreations of the world have a continually decreasing place in the heart of a growing Christian. He does not condemn them as downright sinful, nor say that those who have anything to do with them are going to hell. He only feels they have a constantly diminishing hold on his own affections and gradually seem smaller and more trifling in his eyes.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Experience tells me that people's hearts are seldom changed if they are not changed when young. Seldom indeed are men converted when they are old. Habits have deep roots. Once sin is allowed to settle in your heart, it will not be turned out at your bidding. Custom becomes second nature, and its chains are not easily broken.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Health is a good thing; but sickness is far better, if it leads us to God.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: What could an unsanctified man do in Heaven, if by any chance he got there? No man can possibly be happy in a place where he is not in his element, and where all around him is not congenial to his tastes, habits, and character.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The beginning of the way to heaven, is to feel that we are on the way to hell.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: When an eagle is happy in an iron cage, when a sheep is happy in water, when an owl is happy in the blaze of the noonday sun, when a fish is happy on dry land - then, and not till then, will I admit that the unsanctified man could be happy in heaven.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Disbelieve hell, and you unscrew, unsettle, and unpin everything in Scripture.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: If I never spoke of hell, I should think I had kept back something that was profitable, and should look on myself as an accomplice of the devil.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The saddest road to hell is the one that runs under the pulpit, past the Bible, and through the middle of warnings and invitations.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The whole extent of hell, the present suffering, the bitter recollection of the past, the hopeless prospect of the future, will never be thoroughly known except by those who go there.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: To say that reunion with Rome would be an insult to our martyred Reformers is a very light thing; it is far more than this: it would be sin and an offense against God!
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Holiness is the habit of being of one mind with God, according as we find His mind described in Scripture. It is the habit of agreeing in God's judgment, hating what He hates, loving what He loves, and measuring everything in this world by the standard of His Word.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We must be holy, because this is the only sound evidence that we have a saving faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: I cannot see how any man deserves to be called 'holy,' who willfully allows himself in sins, and is not humbled and ashamed because of them.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: I should as soon expect a farmer to prosper in business who contented himself with sowing his fields and never looking at them till harvest, as expect a believer to attain much holiness who was not diligent about his Bible reading, his prayers, and the use of his Sundays.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: If there is any point on which God's holiest saints agree it is this: that they see more, and know more, and feel more, and do more, and repent more, and believe more, as they get on in spiritual life, and in proportion to the closeness of their walk with God.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: I am convinced that the first step towards attaining a higher standard of holiness is to realize more fully the amazing sinfulness of sin.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: What is the reason that some believers are so much brighter and holier than others? I believe the difference, in nineteen cases out of twenty, arises from different habits about private prayer. I believe that those who are not eminently holy pray little, and those who are eminently holy pray much.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Without holiness on earth we shall never be prepared to enjoy heaven. Heaven is a holy place. The Lord of heaven is a holy Being. The angels are holy creatures. Holiness is written on everything in heaven... How shall we ever be at home and happy in heaven if we die unholy?
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Humility and love are precisely the graces which the men of the world can understand, if they do not comprehend doctrines. They are the graces about which there is no mystery, and they are within reach of all classes. The poorest Christian can every day find occasion for practicing love and humility.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Idleness is the devil's best friend. It is the surest way to give him an opportunity of doing us some harm. An idle mind is like an open door, and if Satan does not come through it himself, it is certain he will throw something in to arouse bad thoughts in us.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: It is not that doing nothing is of itself so wicked; it is the opportunity it affords to evil and empty thoughts; it is the wide door it opens for Satan to throw in the seeds of bad things; it is this which is mainly to be feared.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The name Emmanuel takes in the whole mystery. Jesus is 'God with us.' He had a nature like our own in all things, sin only excepted. But though Jesus was 'with us' in human flesh and blood, He was at the same time very God.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Tell me not of your justification, unless you have also some marks of sanctification. Boast not of Christ's work for you, unless you can show us the Spirit's work in you.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Knowledge, not improved and well employed, will only increase our condemnation at the last day.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Many, I fear, would like glory, who have no wish for grace. They would [want to] have the wages, but not the work; the harvest, but not the labor; the reaping, but not the sowing; the reward, but not the battle. But it may not be.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: You were placed here to train for eternity. Your body was only intended to be a house for your immortal spirit. It is flying in the face of God's purposes to do as many do - to make the soul a servant to the body, and not the body a servant to the soul.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Think about how much falsehood and deceit there is in the world! How much exaggeration! How many untruths are added to a simple story! How many things are left out, if it does not serve the speaker's interest to tell them! How few there are around us of whom we can say, that we trust their word without question!
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Nothing I am sure has such a tendency to quench the fire of religion as the possession of money.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Two-thirds of all the strifes, quarrels and lawsuits in the world arise from one single cause - money!
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Abide in Me says Jesus. Cling to Me. Stick fast to Me. Live the life of close and intimate communion with Me. Get nearer to Me. Roll every burden on Me. Cast your whole weight on Me. Never let go your hold on Me for a moment. Be, as it were, rooted and planted in Me. Do this and I will never fail you. I will ever abide in you.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Obedience is the only reality. It is faith visible, faith acting, and faith manifest. It is the test of real discipleship among the Lord's people.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Fathers and mothers, do not forget that children learn more by the eye than they do by the ear... Imitation is a far stronger principle with children than memory. What they see has a much stronger effect on their minds than what they are told.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Parents, determine to make your children obey you, though it may cost you a lot of trouble, and cost them many tears. Let there be no questioning, and reasoning, and disputing, and delaying. When you give them a command, let them clearly see that you expect them to do it.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Most true is it that what costs little is worth little! A religion which costs us nothing, and consist in nothing but hearing sermons, will always prove at last to be a useless thing.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: To be prayerless is to be without God, without Christ, without grace, without hope, and without heaven.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: A man's state before God may always be measured by his prayers.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: No time is so well spent in every day as that which we spend upon our knees.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We must wrestle earnestly in prayer, like men contending with a deadly enemy for life.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: No prayers can be heard which do not come from a forgiving heart.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Jesus hears us, and in His own good time will give an answer... He may sometimes keep us long waiting...but He will never send us empty away.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Pride comes from not knowing yourself and the world. The older you grow, and the more you see, the less reason you will find for being proud. Ignorance and inexperience are the pedestal of pride; once the pedestal is removed - pride will soon come down.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Let us watch against pride in every shape - pride of intellect, pride of wealth, pride in our own goodness, pride in our own deserts. Nothing is so likely to keep a man out of heaven, and prevent him seeing Christ, as pride. So long as we think we are something, we shall never be saved.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Nothing whatever, whether great or small, can happen to a believer, without God's ordering and permission. There is no such thing as 'chance,' 'luck' or 'accident' in the Christian's journey through this world. All is arranged and appointed by God. And all things are 'working together' for the believer's good.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Be very sure of this - people never reject the Bible because they cannot understand it. They understand it too well; they understand that it condemns their own behavior; they understand that it witnesses against their own sins, and summons them to judgment. They try to believe it is false and useless, because they don't like to believe it is true.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: But depend on it, bad company in this life, is the sure way to procure worse company in the life to come.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: A religion which did not flatter the rich, the great, and the learned - a religion which offered no license to the carnal inclinations of man's heart - a religion whose first teachers were poor fishermen, without wealth, rank, or power - a religion could never have turned the world upside down, if it had not been of God.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: I declare I know of no state of soul more dangerous than to imagine we are born again and sanctified by the Holy Ghost, because we have picked up a few religious feelings.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: True repentance is no light matter. It is a thorough change of heart about sin, a change showing itself in godly sorrow and humiliation - in heartfelt confession before the throne of grace - in a complete breaking off from sinful habits, and an abiding hatred of all sin. Such repentance is the inseparable companion of saving faith in Christ.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Saving faith and real converting grace will always produce some conformity to the image of Jesus.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: One single soul saved shall outlive and outweigh all the kingdoms of the world.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We are evidently no friends of Satan. Like the kings of this world, he wars not against his own subjects. The very fact that he assaults us should fill our minds with hope.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We corrupt the Word of God most dangerously, when we throw any doubt on the plenary inspiration of any part of Holy Scripture.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: All portions of Scripture ought to be approached with deep humility and earnest prayer for the teaching of the Spirit. On no point have good people so entirely disagreed as on the interpretation of prophecy; on no point have the prejudices of one group, the dogmatism of a second and the extravagance of a third done so much to rob the church of truths which God intended to be a blessing.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Give me the plenary, verbal theory of biblical inspiration with all its difficulties, rather than the doubt. I accept the difficulties and humbly wait for their solution. But while I wait, I am standing on the rock.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Whenever a man takes upon him to make additions to the Scriptures, he is likely to end with valuing his own additions above Scripture itself.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Beware of self-righteousness in every possible shape and form. Some people get as much harm from their 'virtues' as others do from their sins.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Stop being so sure that you are always right, and others wrong. Don't trust your own opinion, when you find it contrary to that of older men, and especially to that of your own parents. Age gives experience, and therefore deserves respect.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Let us remember, there is One who daily records all we do for Him, and sees more beauty in His servants' work than His servants do themselves... And then shall His faithful witnesses discover, to their wonder and surprise, that there never was a word spoken on their Master's behalf, which does not receive a reward.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: He that boasts of being one of God's elect, while he is willfully and habitually living in sin, is only deceiving himself, and talking wicked blasphemy.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Once let us see that sin is far viler, and far nearer to us, and sticks more closely to us than we supposed, and we shall be led, I trust and believe, to get nearer to Christ.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: A sin...consists in doing, saying, thinking, or imagining anything that is not in perfect conformity with the mind and law of God
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Christ is never fully valued, until sin is clearly seen. We must know the depth and malignity of our disease, in order to appreciate the great Physician.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: How can we love sin, when we remember that because of our sins Jesus died?
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Let us, then, have it fixed down in our minds that the sinfulness of man does not begin from without, but from within. It is not the result of bad training in early years. It is not picked up from bad companions and bad examples, as some weak Christians are too fond of saying. No! It is a family disease, which we all inherit from our first parents, Adam and Eve, and with which we are born.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Sin forsaken is one of the best evidences of sin forgiven.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Sin must indeed be exceeding sinful, when the Father must needs give His only Son to be the sinner's Friend!
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The servant of Christ must never be surprised if he has to drink of the same cup with His Lord.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The chief weapon we ought to use in resisting Satan is the Bible. Three times the great enemy offered temptations to our Lord. Three times his offer was refused, with a text of Scripture as the reason, 'it is written' (Mt. 3:4, 7, 10).
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: To be tempted is in itself no sin. It is the yielding to the temptation, and giving it a place in our hearts, which we must fear.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We must not count temptation a strange thing. 'The disciple is not greater than his master, nor the servant than his lord.' If Satan came to Christ, he will also come to Christians.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: The Bible in the pulpit must never supersede the Bible at home.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: If Christ had not gone to the cross and suffered in our stead, the just for the unjust, there would not have been a spark of hope for us. There would have been a mighty gulf between ourselves and God, which no man ever could have passed.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Take away the cross of Christ, and the Bible is a dark book.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: It would have been well for the church of Christ, if the warnings of the Gospel had been as much studied as its promises.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: It was the whole Trinity, which at the beginning of creation said, 'Let us make man'. It was the whole Trinity again, which at the beginning of the Gospel seemed to say, 'Let us save man'.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: We should never desert a great principle in theology any more than in science, because of apparent difficulties which we are not able at present to remove.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Too many are apt to look at nothing but the surface of things in religion, and regard nice distinctions in theology as questions of 'words and names,' which are of little real value.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Never let us be guilty of sacrificing any portion of truth on the altar of peace.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: To maintain pure truth in the church, we should be ready to make any sacrifice, to hazard peace, to risk dissention and run the chance of division.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Unity without the gospel is a worthless unity; it is the very unity of hell.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Our Lord has many weak children in his family, many dull pupils in his school, many raw soldiers in his army, many lame sheep in his flock. Yet he bears with them all, and casts none away. Happy is that Christian who has learned to do likewise with his brethren.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: There is a common, worldly kind of Christianity in this day, which many have, and think they have enough - a cheap Christianity which offends nobody, and requires no sacrifice - which costs nothing, and is worth nothing.
author: J.C. Ryle

quote: Wisdom is the power to see and the inclination to choose the best and highest goal, together with the surest means of attaining it.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Our business is to present the Christian faith clothed in modern terms, not to propagate modern thought clothed in Christian terms... Confusion here is fatal.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: It is here, in the thing that happened at the first Christmas, that the most profound unfathomable depths of the Christian revelation lie. God became man; Nothing in fiction is so fantastic as this truth of the incarnation.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The Almighty appeared on earth as a helpless human baby, needing to be fed and changed and taught to talk like any other child. The more you think about it, the more staggering it gets. Nothing in fiction is so fantastic as this truth of the Incarnation.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The Christmas message is that there is hope for a ruined humanity--hope of pardon, hope of peace with God, hope of glory--because at the Father's will Jesus became poor, and was born in a stable so that thirty years later He might hang on a cross.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Doctrinal preaching certainly bores the hypocrites; but it is only doctrinal preaching that will save Christ's sheep.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The unceasing activity of the Creator, whereby in overflowing bounty and goodwill, He upholds His creatures in ordered existence, guides and governs all events, circumstances, and free acts of angels and men, and directs everything to its appointed goal, for His own glory.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Nothing can alter the character of God. In the course of a human life, tastes and outlook and temper may change radically: a kin, equable man may turn bitter and crotchety: a man of good-will may grow cynical and callous. But nothing of this sort happens to the Creator.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Knowing God is more than knowing about Him; it is a matter of dealing with Him as He opens up to you, and being dealt with by Him as He takes knowledge of you. Knowing about Him is a necessary precondition of trusting in Him, but the width of our knowledge about Him is no gauge of our knowledge of Him.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The character of God is today, and always will be, exactly what it was in Bible times. God is forever what at that moment, three thousand years ago, He told Moses that He was.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: What were we made for? To know God. What aim should we have in life? To know God. What is the eternal life that Jesus gives? To know God. What is the best thing in life? To know God. What in humans gives God most pleasure? Knowledge of himself.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: I am graven on the palms of His hands. I am never out of His mind. All my knowledge of Him depends on His sustained initiative in knowing me. I know Him, because He first knew me, and continues to know me. He knows me as a friend, One who loves me; and there is no moment when His eye is off me, or His attention distracted for me, and no moment, therefore, when His care falters.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: I saw myself standing outside a house looking in on a tremendous party with laughter and joy. The Lord tracked me down and found me. I was surprised by grace. I became an avid Bible reader and my initial doubts soon evaporated in the atmosphere of solid Bible exposition at the Christian Union.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: What matters supremely, therefore, is not, in the last analysis, the fact that I know God, but the larger fact which underlies it - the fact that He knows me.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The way to be truly happy is to be truly human, and the way to be truly human is to be truly godly.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: We are to order our lives by the light of His Law, not by our guesses about His plan.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The weaker we feel, the harder we lean. And the harder we lean, the stronger we grow spiritually, even while our bodies waste away.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Any idea of getting beyond conflict, outward or inward, in our pursuit of holiness in this world is an escapist dream that can only have disillusioning and demoralizing effects on us as waking experience daily disproves it. What we must realize, rather, is that any real holiness in us will be under hostile fire all the time, just as our Lord's was.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Not until we have become humble and teachable, standing in awe of God's holiness and sovereignty. acknowledging our own littleness, distrusting our own thoughts, and willing to have our minds turned upside down, can divine wisdom become ours.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: He sees all the twisted things about me that my fellow-men do not see (and I am glad!), and that He sees more corruption in me than that which I see in myself (which, in all conscience, is enough).
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The focus of health in the soul is humility, while the root of inward corruption is pride. In the spiritual life, nothing stands still. If we are not constantly growing downward into humility, we shall be steadily swelling up and running to seed under the influence of pride.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The impression of Jesus which the Gospels give is not so much one of deity reduced as of divine capacities restrained.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The truth is that, though we were justified by faith alone, the faith that justifies is never alone (it always produces fruit, 'good works,'...a transformed life).
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Once you become aware that the main business that you are here for is to know God, most of life's problems fall into place of their own accord.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: The Puritan ethic of marriage was first to look not for a partner whom you do love passionately at this moment but rather for one whom you can love steadily as your best friend for life, then to proceed with God's help to do just that.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Jesus' pattern prayer, which is both crutch, road, and walking lesson for the spiritually lame like ourselves, tells us to start with God: for God matters infinitely more than we do.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Confidence that one's impressions are God-given is no guarantee that this is really so, even when they persist and grow stronger through long seasons of prayer. Bible-based wisdom must judge them.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: We must learn to measure ourselves, not by our knowledge about God, not by our gifts and responsibilities in the church, but by how we pray and what goes on in our hearts. Many of us, I suspect, have no idea how impoverished we are at this level. Let us ask the Lord to show us.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: (The Puritans believed in) the supreme importance of preaching. To the Puritans, the sermon was the liturgical climax of public worship. Nothing, they said, honours God more than the faithful declaration and obedient hearing of His truth. Preaching, under any circumstances, is an act of worship, and must be performed as such. Moreover, preaching is the prime means of grace to the church.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Underlying the preaching of the Puritans are three basic axioms: 1. The unique place of preaching is to convert, feed and sustain, 2. The life of the preacher must radiate the reality of what he preaches, 3. Prayer and solid Bible study are basic to effective preaching.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: We complain today that ministers do not know how to preach; but is it not equally true that our congregations do not know how to hear?
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Repentance is more than just sorrow for the past; repentance is a change of mind and heart, a new life of denying self and serving the Savior as king in self's place.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Repentance, as we know, is basically not moaning and remorse, but turning and change.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Christians in revival are accordingly found living in God's presence (Coram Deo), attending to His Word, feeling acute concern about sin and righteousness, rejoicing in the assurance of Christ's love and their own salvation, spontaneously constant in worship, and tirelessly active in witness and service, fueling these activities by praise and prayer.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Revival is the visitation of God which brings to life Christians who have been sleeping and restores a deep sense of God's near presence and holiness. Thence springs a vivid sense of sin and a profound exercise of heart in repentance, praise, and love, with an evangelistic outflow.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: There is, however, equally great incentive to worship and love God in the thought that, for some unfathomable reason, He wants me as His friend, and desires to be my friend, and has given His Son to die for me in order to realize this purpose. not merely that we know God, but that He knows us.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: There's a difference between knowing God and knowing about God. When you truly know God, you have energy to serve him, boldness to share him, and contentment in him.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Have you been holding back from a risky, costly course to which you know in your heart God has called you? Hold back no longer. Your God is faithful to you, and adequate for you. You will never need more than He can supply, and what He supplies, both materially and spiritually, will always be enough for the present.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Calvary not merely made possible the salvation of those for whom Christ died; it ensured that they would be brought to faith and their salvation made actual.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: Revelation does not mean man finding God, but God finding man, God sharing His secrets with us, God showing us Himself. In revelation, God is the agent as well as the object.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: We need to discover all over again that worship is natural to the Christian, as it was to the godly Israelites who wrote the psalms, and that the habit of celebrating the greatness and graciousness of God yields an endless flow of thankfulness, joy, and zeal.
author: J.I. Packer

quote: God does not choose those who are fit. He outfits those whom He chooses.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The man who gets ahead is the man who works while others sleep.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is nothing wrong with America that cannot be cured by old-fashioned preaching.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The greatest blessing in the whole world is being a blessing.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If we prepare ourselves for life's inevitables, we will not be perplexed by life's transitions.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A good name is what is given you by others and that which has been earned by you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If you do what you always did, you'll get what you always got.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Let principles make decisions.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: What you are is what it takes to stop you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Character comes by repetition of right until right is done subconsciously.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The Christian life is a way of life.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A Christian ought to feel that when a need arises, it is his duty to fill that need.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A church doesn't necessarily need space to grow; it just needs the power of God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: To lose something in the will of God is to find something better.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The man who gets ahead is the man who works while others sleep. The people who do great works for God are those who are content and stay at their job.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Until we are willing to die, we have no right to live.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Let's be diligent in giving, careful in our living, and faithful in our praying.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The best way to help those who are behind you is to heed those before you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: So live that when you find yourself, you will still be qualified to be yourself.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Greatness is in the preparation, not in the performance.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If a task is worthy of our attention, it is worthy of our best.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Make no provisions for failure.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Failure means I dared try.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Failing is not a disgrace unless you make it the last chapter of your book.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Faith is the willingness to risk anything on God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Faith is the key that unlocks all of God's cupboards.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Faith is asking. Faith is believing. Faith is doubting. Faith is stepping out anyway.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Living by faith is believing that God knows what is best for me.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You do not have to seek God's will when you are doing God's will.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I'd rather die in the will of God than to live outside of it.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Effort, weakness, trust, victory: that's my biography.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Remind your mind to use His mind.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A person who has not done well the little is not prepared or qualified to do the big.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Do not ask for fears to be removed; ask for courage equal to the fears.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The fire doesn't make you what you are; it reveals what you were.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A friend cannot be known in prosperity. An enemy cannot be hidden in adversity.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Nobody 'used to love' anyone; there is no such thing as an 'ex-friend.'
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The ones who disappoint you need you the most.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A friend will not try to change your convictions.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A request from a friend is a royal command.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Silence between friends says that one's presence is enough.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: To please a friend is a welcome bonus; to help him is the great reward.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: True friendship needs no reciprocation.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Hearts are united when they ache and break together.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If I and a need meet, God must have had in mind my filling it.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Giving is the true barometer of love.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God's normal dealings with man are very quiet.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: We need God as much in the calm as in the storm.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I know enough of God to want to know more.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You can't come back to God because He is already there.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: How can you give up the world? Just do what you ought to do, and it will give you up.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: It is easy to be grateful for a bonus; it is character to be grateful for a salary.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The pursuit of things robs me of investing more in the work of Christ.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Jesus makes you happy in reality. The world makes you happy escaping from reality.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Happiness is untested delight. Joy is delight tested.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Nothing is happy until it fulfills the purpose for which it was created by God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The right walk can only come from the right stand.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I'll walk with man while he is awake. I'll walk with God while man is asleep.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Clay is earth with humility.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Back of the clouds, the sun is always shining.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is no greater joy in the Christian life than to trust Him and need no explanation.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Laughter means nothing unless there have been tears.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A tear today is an investment in a laugh tomorrow.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Nobody is fit to be a leader unless he would rather be a follower instead of a leader.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The leader must be alone while others are with each other.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Real leaders would rather follow.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The follower is as important as the leader.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Leadership is made for service.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Leadership is forced on a man who is prepared but unaware.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Leadership always has to be learning.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The wise follower will want to build strong leaders.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Life is too short not to spend it doing what God wants us to do.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is no one big will of God for your life, God has many wills for your life.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: What we do today is more important than what we plan to do in the future.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The best thing I can do for you is to love you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is a gift of God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: He Who can love as no man can love can hurt as no man can hurt.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You will never really love until you love someone who hates you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Being loved is life's second greatest blessing; loving is the greatest.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Just to love, that's enough; being loved, that's a bonus.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If I have ever loved you, I will always love you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is a verb.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is a heavenly quality that is given to prepare men to enjoy the heavenly city more.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is hope when reason despairs.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is thinking.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Love is the doorway through which the human soul passes from selfishness to service.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The more you learn to love, the fewer people you will have to love you as you love them.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I cannot love you as I love myself until I love God as I ought to love Him.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I can't make you love me, but you can't keep me from loving you.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Meditation is love's nourishment.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Man's greatest need is to need.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A man's main business is God; a woman's main business is the man.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God never leads anyone anywhere for money.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: He who cannot obey cannot command.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You express love by obedience.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Your faith level is determined by your obedience level.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is always a prepared place for a prepared person.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The reward that outdoes all others is the peace of knowing that you did right.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A prepared person will always have his opportunity.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: When you get to the top, raise the top and climb some more.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If there is a secret in my life it is this: I do everything by schedule.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: My mother said, 'Son, it's the I CAN that makes a great man.'
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God's mighty power comes when God's people learn to walk with God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Preaching is fire in the pulpit that melts the ice in the pew.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Preaching is truth set on fire.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Preaching is sin's greatest adversary.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Preaching is the moral conscience of a nation.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Preaching is teaching with a tear in the eye.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Lord, help me to preach today as if it were the last sermon I would ever preach.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If God feeds me, He has a right to expect my life.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I thank God that I have known hunger; I know what it is for God to feed me.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The thing that God wants from us more than anything else is our dependency on Him.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A person who will not take care of the little things will not take care of the big things, for big things are but an accumulation of little things.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A little person in a little place can use a little thing, perform a little task, and receive a great reward.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Duty and love always accompany each other.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If I live for self, I can only live for one; if I live for others, I can live for 3,000,000,000.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is nothing in this world so empty as getting what you want.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Too may people today ask God 'where' instead of 'what.'
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is nothing more blessed than to be used of God.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If God called us to a task, He will then qualify us for the job.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God's people cannot be shamed into serving God; they need to be challenged.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You don't get strength for the load; you get strength from the load.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God never gives us anything to do that He does not give us the strength to do.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Success is on the same road as failure; success is just a little further down the road.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The difference between success and failure is work.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If I labor for God, I fail. If I labor with God, I succeed.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: You stay successful the same way you became successful.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: To lose something in the will of God is to find something better.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: God won't do for you what you can do for yourself.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Suffering is the strongest and closest fellowship in the world.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I must have every Word if I speak His message. If I didn't think I had a perfect Bible I'd close this one, walk out that door, I'd never walk in the pulpit again.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: It is tragic for our God, Who gave us His Son to die on the cross, to beg us to love Him.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Everything you declare with your lips will be tested in your life.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I never had a trial I wanted to have, but I never had trial I wasn't glad I had.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: A tribulation gives you the opportunity to test a truth you have always believed.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If you can't see His goodness, you can trust His goodness.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: If you hold the truth while you are in danger, the truth will hold you when you are in danger.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: I'd rather be right wrongly than wrong rightly.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Nothing unites people as sharing the same affliction.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: On the essentials, unity. On the nonessentials, liberty. In everything, charity.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The victory comes not to the one who is the most talented but to the one who labors more abundantly than them all.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There is no victory in the world any more shallow than victory over another.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: It is not easy to lose, but often more is won in loss than victory.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: The war is not won on the battlefield; it is won in the boot camp.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: There are two ways to be rich in life: have what you want or want what you have.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: Use your work to build your people, not your people to build your work.
author: Jack Hyles

quote: He that has never known adversity but half acquainted with others or himself.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Afflictions are but conductors to immortal life and glory.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: It is not affliction itself, but affliction rightly borne, that does us good.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The wisdom of God appears in afflictions. By these He separates the sin which He hates, from the son whom He loves. By these thorns He keeps him from breaking over into Satan's pleasant pastures, which would fatten him indeed, but only to the slaughter.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Cheerfulness is the friend and helper of all good graces, and the absence of it is certainly a vice.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Cheerfulness sharpens the edge and removes the rust from the mind. A joyous heart supplies oil to our inward machinery, and makes the whole of our powers work with ease and efficiency; hence it is of the utmost importance that we maintain a contented, cheerful, genial disposition.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Christ is the Good Physician. There is no disease He cannot heal; no sin He cannot remove; no trouble He cannot help. He is the Balm of Gilead, the Great Physician who has never yet failed to heal all the spiritual maladies of every soul that has come unto Him in faith and prayer.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: On the head of Christ are many crowns. He wears the crown of victory; He wears the crown of sovereignty; He wears the crown of creation; He wears the crown of providence; He wears the crown of grace; He wears the crown of glory - for every one of His glorified people owes his honor, happiness and blessedness to Him.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Our Christianity is a name, a shadow, unless, we resemble Him who, being the incarnate God, was incarnate goodness.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Where science speaks of improvement, Christianity speaks of renovation; where science speaks of development, Christianity speaks of sanctification; where science of progress, Christianity speaks of perfection.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: A little thing will keep them from the house of God who have no desire to go to it.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The church is not a select circle of the immaculate, but a home where the outcast may come in. It is not a palace with gate attendants and challenging sentinels along the entrance-ways holding off at arm's-length the stranger, but rather a hospital where the broken-hearted may be healed, and where all the weary and troubled may find rest and take counsel together.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Conscience is the voice of God in the soul.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Good conscience is sometimes sold for money, but never bought with it.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: A cheerful spirit is one of the most valuable gifts ever bestowed upon humanity by a kind Creator. It is the sweetest and most fragrant flower of the Spirit, that constantly sends out its beauty and fragrance, and blesses everything within its reach. It will sustain the soul in the darkest and most dreary places of this world. It will hold in check the demons of despair, and stifle the power of discouragement and hopelessness. It is the brightest star that ever cast its radiance over the darkened soul, and one that seldom sets in the gloom of morbid fancies and forboding imaginations.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Death to the Christian is the funeral of all his sorrows and evils, and the resurrection, of all his joys.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: I have seen many men and women of fashion die, and I never saw one of them die well. The trappings off, there they lay on the tumbled pillow, and there were just two things that bothered them, a wasted life and a coming eternity.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: It unfortunately happens that no man believes that he is likely to die soon. So every one is much disposed to defer the consideration of what ought to be done on the supposition of such an emergency; and while nothing is so uncertain as human life, so nothing is so certain as our assurance that we shall survive most of our neighbors.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Open your heart to sympathy, but close it against despondency. The flower which opens to receive the dew shuts against the rain.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Nothing is eternal but that which is done for God and others. That which is done for self dies.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Palaces and pyramids are reared by laying one brick, or block, at a time; and the kingdom of Christ is enlarged by individual conversions.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The mission of the Church is to seek and to save them that are lost.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: A firm faith is the best theology; a good life is the best philosophy; a clear conscience the best law; honesty, the best policy, and temperance the best physic.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: As a weak limb grows stronger by exercise, so will your faith be strengthened by the very efforts you make in stretching it out toward things unseen.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Faith without evidence is, properly, not faith, but prejudice or presumption; faith beyond evidence is superstition, and faith contrary to evidence is either insanity or willful perversity of mind.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The soul is the life of the body, faith is the life of the soul, and Christ is the life of faith. Justification by faith in Christ's righteousness is the golden chain which binds the Christian world in one body.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Were it not for an unquestioning faith, human progress would be an intolerable burden.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Ye do well to remember that habitual affectionate communion with God, asking Him for all good which is needed, praising Him for all that is received, and trusting Him for future supplies, prevents anxious cares, inspires peace, calmness and composure, and furnishes a delight surpassing all finite comprehension.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Youth, beauty, wit may recommend you to men, but only faith in Jesus Christ can recommend you to God.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Many men affect to despise fear, and in preaching resent any appeal to it; but not to fear when there is occasion is as great a weakness as to fear unduly without reason. God implanted fear in the soul as truly as He implanted hope or courage.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Debt is the secret foe of thrift, as vice and idleness are its open enemies.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: God strikes not as an enemy, to destroy; but as a father, to correct.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: One improper word or act will neutralize the effect of many good ones; and one base deed, after years of noble service, will cover them all with shame.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: All Christian power springs from communion with God and from the indwelling of divine grace.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: There is dew in one flower and not in another, because one opens its cup and takes it in, while the other closes itself and the drop runs off. So God rains goodness and mercy as wide as the dew, and if we lack them, it is because we do not open our hearts to receive them.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Five, or six, ten people shall be made temporarily wretched because one person, unconsciously perhaps, yet supremely, egotistic and selfish, has never learned to control his disposition and bridle his tongue.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Happiness and comfort stream immediately from God himself, as light issues from the sun; and sometimes looks and darts itself into the meanest corners, while it forbears to visit the largest and the noblest rooms.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Happiness without peace is temporal; peace along with happiness is eternal.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: There is no man that goeth to heaven but he must go by the cross. The cross is the standing way-mark which all they that go to glory must pass by.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The great comprehensive truths written in letters of living light on every page of our history are these: Human happiness has no perfect security but freedom; freedom none but virtue; virtue none but knowledge; and neither freedom nor virtue has any vigor of immortal hope, except in the principles of Christian faith, and in the sanctions of the Christian religion.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Holiness consists of three things - separation from sin, dedication to God, transformation into Christ's image. It is in vain that we talk about the last, unless we know something experimentally about the first.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Remember that holiness is not the way to Christ, but Christ is the way to holiness.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: A hope unaccompanied with a godly life had better be given up, and the sooner the better; for, if retained, it will prove as a spider's web when God shall take away the soul.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Hope is the last lingering light of the human heart. It shines when every other is put out. Extinguish it, and the gloom of affliction becomes the very blackness of darkness - cheerless and impenetrable.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Be deaf to the quarrelsome, blind to the scorner and dumb to the inquisitive.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The most holy men are always the most humble men; none so humble on earth as those that live highest in heaven.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The ability to find fault is believed, by some people, to be a sure sign of great wisdom, when, in most cases, it only indicates narrowness of mind and ill nature.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: None should expect to prosper who go out of way of duty.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: It is a high, solemn, almost awful thought for every individual man, that his earthly influence, which has a commencement, will never, through all ages, have an end.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Let not the stream of your life be a murmuring stream.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Lost time is never found again.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: There are many seasons in a man's life - and the more exalted and responsible his position, the more frequently do these season's recur - when the voice of duty and the dictates of feeling are opposed to each other; and it is only the weak and the wicked who yield that obedience to the selfish impulses of the heart which is due to reason and honor.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Sensual pleasures are like soap-bubbles, sparkling, evanescent. The pleasures of intellect are calm, beautiful, sublime, ever enduring and climbing upward to the borders of the unseen world.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: As every mercy is a drop obtained from the ocean of God's goodness, so every affliction is a drachm weighed out in the wisdom of God's providence.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The most generous and merciful in judgment upon the faults of others, are always the most free from faults themselves.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: No books are so legible as the lives of men; no character so plain as their moral conduct.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: God's corrections are our instructions; His lashes our lessons, and His scourges our schoolmasters.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Jesus organized the church, which is His vineyard. He commands all to go into the vineyard and work. All who are united to Christ by faith, and are thus members of His mystical body, should be members of His visible church.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Do daily and hourly your duty; do it patiently and thoroughly. Do it as it presents itself; do it at the moment, and let it be its own reward. Never mind whether it is known and acknowledged or not, but do not fail to do it.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Great things are not accomplished by idle dreams, but by years of patient study.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: He who bears failure with patience is as much of a philosopher as he who succeeds; for to put up with the world needs as much wisdom as to control it.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: All our murmurings are so many arrows shot at God Himself, and they will return upon our own hearts; they reach not Him, but they will hit us; they hurt not Him, but they will wound us; therefore it is better to be mute than to murmur; it is dangerous to provoke a consuming fire.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: When our will runs parallel with the will of God, no cross is formed; but when our will runs counter to God's will, a cross is formed which is heavy to be borne.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Should you suffer your weary soul this day to sink into the arms of that Saviour who rejoices to pardon and is mighty to save, the first entrance of such a word, and the first response of such a faith, would be the date of your better life and the commencement of your union to Christ. The graft has taken. At first the juncture may be very slight - a single thread or fiber - and it is not till you try to part them that you find that they are knit together; that their life is one, and that the force which plucks away the graft must also wound the vine. And your faith may yet be no more than a single filament. It may be only one point of attachment by which you are joined to the Lord Jesus. It may be only one solitary sentence, one isolated invitation or promise, of which you have undoubting hold. But hold it fast. If it be the word of Jesus, cling to it.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: In the Church of Christ one little worker can mar the whole by failing to fulfill his office. There is a place for each. Find your place if you are not already in it, and obey the Saviour's command, 'Go work in my vineyard' - the command of a king which you disobey at the peril of losing the reward of the faithful.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: It is one of the worst of errors to suppose that there is any other path of safety except that of duty.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The church is made up of individuals. It can do nothing except as its members work, and work together.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Difficulty excites the mind to the dignity which sustains and finally conquers misfortunes, and the ordeal refines while it chastens.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: God brings men into deep waters not to drown them, but to cleanse them.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: God makes crosses of great variety; He makes some of iron and lead, that look as if they must crush; some of straw, that seem so light, and yet are no less difficult to carry; some He makes of precious stones and gold, that dazzle the eye and excite the envy of spectators, but in reality are as well able to crucify as those which are so much dreaded.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: Sorrow comes soon enough without despondency. It does a man no good to carry around a lightning-rod to attract trouble.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: The chief secret of comfort lies in not suffering trifles to vex us, and in prudently cultivating an undergrowth of small pleasures, since very few great ones are let on long leases.
author: James H. Aughey

quote: This is one of the sad conditions of life, that experience is not transmissible. No man will learn from the suffering of another; he must suffer himself.
author: James H. Aughey
