quote: Without the heart it is not worship; it is a stage play; an acting a part without being that person really a hypocrite. We may truly be said to worship God-though we lack perfection; but we cannot be said to worship Him if we lack sincerity.
author: Stephen Charnock

quote: A man may be theologically knowing and spiritually ignorant.
author: Stephen Charnock

quote: In regard of God, patience is a submission to His sovereignty. To endure a trial, simply because we cannot avoid or resist it, is not Christian patience. But to humbly submit because it is the will of God to inflict the trial, to be silent because the sovereignty of God orders it - is true godly patience.
author: Stephen Charnock

quote: We may be truly said to worship God, though we lack perfection; but we cannot be said to worship Him if we lack sincerity.
author: Stephen Charnock

quote: Only a love for the truth and a willingness to do what the Word of God says will preserve us from the apostasy that Scripture tells us will overtake the world.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: Many evangelical churches have become a major referral source for secular psychotherapists; shepherds more often than not are committing their sheep to such God-denying hirelings for resolving life's issues.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: The church has been so seduced by psychological counseling for so long that anything that seems at odds with the current counseling practices is usually considered a consequence of ignorance.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: A worker who has done a good job can boast or feel a sense of pride in the work he has accomplished. Yet all of that is contrary to grace or a gift. Grace rules out any sense of merit, and a gift does away with any sense of something earned or paid for.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: Most biblical counseling is trapped in a 'just fix the problem' or 'get rid of the symptoms' mentality and mode, along with other concepts that are contrary to the biblical way.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: When attempts are made by Christians to combine psychology with the teachings of Scripture, it is, wittingly or unwittingly, the addition of 'a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death' (Proverbs 14:12) and a variation of the 'Yea, hath God said...?' dialogue, resulting in the corruption of God's Word.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: [The] humanistic cornerstone of self-love has become a new doctrine within evangelical Christianity, taught from many of the most popular pulpits. Sermons more often than not quote psychologists and teach their unbiblical psychological concepts for credibility.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: In addition to being completely blasphemous and a deadly form of occultism that deters people from seeking medical help, the healing and prosperity movement spawns ultimate rebellion in the name of God.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: When we compare biblical Christianity with the religions of the world, using the Scriptures to guide us, we see that the gap between them is unbridgeable. In fact, one is forced to the conclusion that there are really only two religions in the world: biblical Christianity--and all other religions.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: The very thought that he could entice the Lord, his Creator, to 'fall down and worship' him (Matthew 4:9) demonstrates not only his egotistic ambition but also just how self-absorbed and self-deceived he is. This is a major trait of humanity as well.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: Although humans have been enamored with themselves since the Garden of Eden, there is no generation in history that has been so preoccupied with self, even to the point of making self the key to solving all of mankind's problems.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: God hasn't completely eliminated suffering from anyone's life. Jesus, who is both God and the perfect, sinless Man, nevertheless suffered as a man on this earth.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: For those who have not yet turned to the Lord for His salvation, their condition of suffering often creates compelling opportunities for them to cry out to God for His help. To those who do so in truth, He shows His mercy for their temporal plight and provides grace for their new life in Christ and their eternal destiny.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: For the believer in Jesus, every trial of suffering is an opportunity to grow in the faith, to grow in our relationship with the Lord, and to see Him work in our lives in a uniquely personal way that demonstrates His compassion, His comfort, His tender mercies, His loving kindnesses, His grace, and His endless love. Only God knows what each of us needs to experience and learn in order to be 'conformed to the image of his Son'.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: The primary way a relationship with Jesus develops is by reading the revelation of Himself given in His Word. This is the only way to obtain specific information about Him that is objective and absolutely true.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: It is hard for anyone who has a personal, intimate relationship with Jesus Christ to accept that the world hates Him, this One whom we love so much... I thought of the Lord of Glory hanging upon the cross on Calvary's hill, with the mockers about Him. Yet He died for them--and for those who mock Him still.
author: T.A. McMahon

quote: You face your greatest opposition when your closest to your biggest miracle.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Your latter days are supposed to be greater than your former days.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: All over this nation, all over this world there are people going to church today and they say they are believers, but until you can take what you've been taught and bring it to the place you gave up--you will never be the radical believer that you need to be for the times in which we live.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: All of us have not been to a natural prison, but everybody in here has had a spiritual prison.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: If your in anything and never wanted to quit it--your not in much.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It is God's objective to make your condition line up with your position.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You are no stronger than your belief system.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Isn't it funny how something that will later be a blessing can be a curse if you get it too soon.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You don't have to sin to be carnal. People who are carnal just means they make all their decisions based on their senses.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It is possible for you to get a grip on the thing that used to have a grip on you. And instead of it controlling you--you are now controlling it.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Anything that does not affect your destiny is up to you.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It does matter where you go to church, it does matter where you worship, it does matter where you lift your head, it does matter where you cry out to God. There is something about the atmosphere. I might be lame, but put me in the atmosphere. I may be drunk, but put me in the atmosphere. I may be weak, but put me in the atmosphere.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: There is a higher power, a higher influence, a God who rules and reigns and controls circumstances and situations that are beyond your area and realm of authority.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Baptism was to put a line of demarcation between your past sins when you are buried with Him by Baptism--you are burying your past sins--eradicating them--putting a line in the sand saying that old man is dead and he is no longer alive any more and I rise up to walk in the newness of life.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Come hell or high water you will never take me back to the place I was before. I have been through too much to let life whoop me again. My faith is stronger than it's ever been, my mind is more tenacious than it's ever been, my soul is more absolute.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Even when things are getting worse instead of better--I believe God!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Faith becomes a bridge between where I am and where I want to go--it is a substance.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Faith will get in the ditch with you, faith will go in the prison with you, faith will go into divorce court with you, faith will go in the hospital with you, faith will go in the nursing home with you.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I'm not walking by sight--I'm walking by faith.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Faith must always pass the test of discouragement.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Faith becomes the foundation I'm built on.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Jesus did not teach people to have faith--he said have faith in God.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: The challenge of the believer is to take the faith that you got in here and take it to the place out there.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Whenever you face obstacles, crises and dilemmas and your confidence is in your associates more than in God--it is a sign your faith is deteriorating.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: God will give you anything as long as you understand that he is the primary and not the secondary.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: God's grace is painted on the canvas of despair.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Grace doesn't run from trouble--in fact it looks for trouble as a backdrop so that you can see how strong it is.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You don't know how much you've grown--until trouble comes back for an encore.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You can't have healing without sickness.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It is not about you--it's about what God is going to do in your life!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I don't know about you--but I couldn't live with life without God.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: In order to make this journey--you have to make it without baggage. You can't carry loads of bags with weight on you in order to be free and Jesus gives you an invitation to come unto him. Now you have to come to him--you will not get rest from anybody else. If you go to anybody else your going to find more work.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I can never experience the next realm of glory until I crucify myself.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You will never understand pleasure without pain.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Many of us harbor hidden low self-esteem. We deem everything and everyone more important that ourselves and think that meeting their needs is more important than meeting our own. But if you run out of gas, everyone riding with you will be left stranded.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: The greater the battle--the greater the spoils.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You went down so that you can come up, you cried so that you can rejoice, you mourned so that you can dance, you did without so that you can overcome, you want to tell every devil in hell. Somebody holler the fight is on.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Prayer will get you out of a pinch, prayer will get you out of a crises, prayer will get you out of your dilemma, prayer will get you out of your trouble.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: When you can't do nothing but pray--you've done a whole lot.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You don't even have to be the one praying, but if you get around somebody who really know how to pray--prayer will lift you when you've fallen, prayer will catch you when you've lost your grip, prayer will stop you from going overboard, prayer will bring you out!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I fully intend to preach the word of God to you until there's a difference between how you walk out of here and how you walked in here.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: If you can disappoint yourself as much as you love yourself and you still manage to disappoint yourself then why are you shocked when other people that you love disappoint you.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Isn't it funny how God will let you be at the right place at the right time with the right people to get what you want from the Lord.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Nobody wants somebody who wants them for what they have or the position they're in--you want somebody who wants you for you. In case it all goes crazy and it all turns to dust. I want somebody who loves me in the welfare line, eating gumbo, eating fish,black eyed peas and rice. I want somebody that loves me. God wants you to love him, not his cars, not his house, not his blessing--love him.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Something happens whenever you sacrifice.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Salvation is the root--the resurrection is the fruit.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I came to serve notice on the devil--he is a liar!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: The enemy is great at changing a word or two!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You are not going to defeat this devil with will power--you need the power of God and if you lose your faith you've lost the fight.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You got a devil to fight. If you got to walk around with your eyes closed--go ahead and do it--cause you got a devil to fight. If you got to be lonely and stay by yourself--go ahead and do it--you got....
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I see too many people who are trying to exercise in faith who do not have a relationship with God. The only time they come to God is when they are in dire need in perilous circumstances and they look to Him to get them out of the crises--but they have not built the infrastructure of relationship up under their faith--they are just using God because their in trouble.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: If Jesus didn't come here to save us from our sins, what did he come for? I don't believe that he came to give us cars and Cadillacs and big houses and rings and diamonds and gold and silver.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: Everybody in here got something that you struggle with.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: There are some fires you can't get out of--you've got to go through the fire--you've got to go through the flood--you've got to go through the test--you've got to go through the struggle that you might decrease and he might increase.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You have to recognize as troubles and trials and tests come into your life you have to recognize that there is a God who sits high and looks low and has all power and has all power in his hand and if you want to communicate with the divine you do it by faith.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: If you seek to save your life--you will lose it--but if you will just surrender and just lose your life--for my sake you will find it!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It's not too early to give your life over to the Lord.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You've done everything that you know how to do, you've tried everything and everything has failed, but it's not to late for God--even now!
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: You cannot have victory without conflict.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: I'll give you some symptoms of a sign that your faith is deteriorating--whenever you face all of your problems and you trust only your plans to get you out--it is a sign that your faith is deteriorating.
author: T.D. Jakes

quote: It is a shame for a person to have been a Christian for years but not to have advanced beyond the knowledge of his salvation.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: No believer lives a spiritually isolated life.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Bible-believing churches and pastors could well apply this principle of pointing out faults without offending. We need to be careful that we do not let a carnal spirit divide us and hurt us so the Lord finds it difficult to use us.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: The new life is life 'in Christ'.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: When God forgives, He at once restores.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Perhaps we have been guilty of speaking against someone and have not realized how it may have hurt them. Then when someone speaks against us, we suddenly realize how deeply such words hurt, and we become sensitive to what we have done.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Live as though Christ died yesterday, rose from the grave today, and is coming back tomorrow.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: We must desire to be separated unto the Lord from the world and its evil system. We must reckon ourselves dead to sin and alive to God. This is true positionally, but it can be made true in our spiritual life only as we yield to the Holy Spirit's control.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: The lesson for each believer is to humble himself, not to wait for the Lord to humble him.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: If you have been mistreated, cheated or deceived and if your heart has been right all along, be assured that God knows this. God will eventually vindicate you, but in the meantime you should be confidently aware that God knows the truth concerning what has happened to you. He knows if your heart has been right.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: We are so easily entangled in earthly affairs and so easily consumed with the desire for those things that do not last. We will not live on this earth forever, so even our trials should be viewed in the light of eternity.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Light reveals righteousness, and it also reveals sin.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: First John 3:16 shows that true love is climaxed by our being willing to lay down our lives for fellow believers.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Where do you stand in your relationship with the Lord? People often say, God is good to me, by which they mean that they have experienced good health or prosperity. What a person possesses is not always a safe measure of his dedication to the Lord.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: The Lord made it very plain in the New Testament that believers cannot escape reaping the kind of harvest they sow. We cannot hide our sin; we will not get away with it. The secrets of the night are not hidden from God.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: God has given believers the responsibility of spreading the Gospel to all the world, and we need to use all at our disposal to accomplish this task.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Because the Scriptures say that no murderer has eternal life abiding in him, we need not conclude that a murderer cannot be saved. He can be if he will come to Christ and receive Him as Saviour.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Many people hear the Word of God, but to some of them it is only words; they do not accept it as the Word of God. What a paradox it is that all creation obeys His Word except we who are made in the image of God and have the ability to choose.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: We should never think that once we have given some money and time to the Lord that the rest is ours to do with as we please. All that we have belongs to God, so He should be taken into consideration in everything we do.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Perhaps God has been speaking to you and you wonder why you have troubles. Maybe you have suffered a financial loss and you find it very difficult to understand. Is God speaking to you in an effort to bring you back to Himself? You need to face these matters squarely and be honest with God as He deals with you.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: Remember that the tongue speaks only what is in the heart.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: As we trust God to give us wisdom for today's decisions, He will lead us a step at a time into what He wants us to be doing in the future.
author: Theodore Epp

quote: For these attacks do not contribute to make us frail but rather show us to be what we are.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If thou art willing to suffer no adversity, how wilt thou be the friend of Christ?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Be not angry that you cannot make others as you wish them to be, since you cannot make yourself as you wish to be.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What else does anxiety about the future bring you but sorrow upon sorrow?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: God often gives in one brief moment that which He has for a long time denied.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If thou desire to profit, read with humility, simplicity, and faithfulness; nor even desire the repute of learning.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Everywhere I have sought rest and found it not except sitting apart in a nook with a little book.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Do not be influenced by the importance of the writer, and whether his learning be great or small, but let the love of pure truth draw you to read. Do not inquire, Who said this? but pay attention to what is said.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Occasions of adversity best discover how great virtue or strength each one hath. For occasions do not make a man frail, but they show what he is.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Occasions do not make a man either strong or weak, but they show what he is.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He is truly great who hath a great charity.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: All the glory and beauty of Christ are manifested within, and there He delights to dwell; His visits there are frequent, His condescension amazing, His conversation sweet, His comforts refreshing; and the peace that He brings passeth all understanding.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Sweet shall be your rest if your heart does not reproach you.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Happy is the man who renounces everything which may bring a stain or burden upon his conscience.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He will easily be content and at peace, whose conscience is pure.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: No one can obtain from the Pope a dispensation for never dying.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: It is thy duty oftentimes to do what thou wouldst not; thy duty, too, to leave undone that thou wouldst do.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Remember always your end, and that lost time does not return.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Our dependence upon God ought to be so entire and absolute that we should never think it necessary, in any kind of distress, to have recourse to human consolations.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Intelligence must follow faith, never precede it, and never destroy it.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Faith is required of thee, and a sincere life, not loftiness of intellect, nor deepness in the mysteries of God.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Wait for the Lord. Behave yourself manfully, and be of good courage. Do not be faithless, but stay in your place and do not turn back.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Know all and you will pardon all.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: O Lord, you know what is best for me. Let this or that be done, as you please. Give what you will, how much you will, and when you will.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: God alone satisfies.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: God deceiveth thee not.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: God is able to do more than man can understand.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: There is no creature so small and abject, that it representeth not the goodness of God.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Man proposes, but God disposes.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Oh, how great peace and quietness would he possess who should cut off all vain anxiety and place all his confidence in God.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What canst thou see elsewhere which thou canst not see here? Behold the heaven and the earth and all the elements; for of these are all things created.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He who loveth God with all his heart feareth not death, nor punishment, nor judgment, nor hell, because perfect love giveth sure access to God. But he who still delighteth in sin, no marvel if he is afraid of death and judgment.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Of two evils, the less is always to be chosen.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He rides pleasantly enough whom the grace of God carries.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: For the multitude of worldly friends profiteth not, nor may strong helpers anything avail, nor wise counselors give profitable counsel, nor the cunning of doctors give consolation, nor riches deliver in time of need, nor a secret place to defend, if Thou, Lord, do not assist, help, comfort, counsel, inform, and defend.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Habit is overcome by habit.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Few spirits are made better by the pain and languor of sickness; as few great pilgrims become eminent saints.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: For a small reward, a man will hurry away on a long journey; while for eternal life, many will hardly take a single step.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Blessed is the pilgrim, who in every place, and at all times of this his banishment in the body, calling upon the holy name of Jesus, calleth to mind his native heavenly land, where his blessed Master, the King of saints and angels, waiteth to receive him. Blessed is the pilgrim who seeketh not an abiding place unto himself in this world; but longeth to be dissolved, and be with Christ in heaven.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If thou bear the cross cheerfully, it will bear thee.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If thou hadst simplicity and purity, thou wouldst be able to comprehend all things without error, and behold them without danger. The pure heart safely pervades not only heaven, but hell.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Purity and simplicity are the two wings with which man soars above the earth and all temporary nature. Simplicity is in the intention, purity in the affection; simplicity turns to God; purity unites with and enjoys him.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Whoever would fully and feelingly understand the words of Christ, must endeavor to conform his life wholly to the life of Christ.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: At the Day of Judgment we shall not be asked what we have read but what we have done; not how well we have spoken, but how holy we have lived.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Learn to break your own will. Be zealous against yourself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: All men are frail, but thou shouldst reckon none so frail as thyself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: No conflict is so severe as his who labors to subdue himself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Our own opinion of ourselves should be lower than that formed by others, for we have a better chance at our imperfections.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He is truly great that is little in himself, and that maketh no account of any height of honors.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What difference does it make to you what someone else becomes, or says, or does? You do not need to answer for others, only for yourself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: God walks with the humble; he reveals himself to the lowly; he gives understanding to the little ones; he discloses his meaning to pure minds, but hides his grace from the curious and the proud.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: No man can ever lack this mortification of his vanity, that what he knows is but a very little in comparison of what he is ignorant of. Consider this, and instead of boasting thy knowledge of a few things, confess and be out of countenance for the many more which thou dost not understand.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Activate yourself to duty by remembering your position, who you are, and what you have obliged yourself to be.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: An humble knowledge of thyself is a surer way to God than a deep search after learning.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Great tranquility of heart is his who cares for neither praise not blame.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: It is easier not to speak a word at all than to speak more words than we should.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The acknowledgment of our weakness is the first step in repairing our loss.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Who has a harder fight than he who is striving to overcome himself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He has great tranquillity of heart who cares neither for the praises nor the fault-finding of men.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: You are not holier if you are praised, nor the more worthless if you are found fault with.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What you are, that you are; neither by word can you be made greater than what you are in the sight of God.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If thou canst not make thyself such an one as thou wouldst, how canst thou expect to have another in all things to thy liking?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: In judging of others, a man laboreth in vain, often erreth and easily sinneth; but in judging and examining himself, he always laboreth fruitfully.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Gladly we desire to make other men perfect, but we will not amend our own fault.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: How seldom we weigh our neighbor in the same balance with ourselves.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If you cannot mold yourself entirely as you would wish, how can you expect other people to be entirely to your liking?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Out of sight, out of mind. The absent are always in the wrong.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Never be entirely idle; but either be reading, or writing, or praying or meditating or endeavoring something for the public good.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: In Jesus and for Him, enemies and friends alike are to be loved.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Without the way, there is no going; without the truth, there is no knowing; without the life, there is no living.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The reflections on a day well spent furnish us with joys more pleasing than ten thousand triumphs.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: So fixed are our spirits in slothfulness and cold indifference that we seldom overcome so much as one evil habit.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: That learning which thou gettest by thy own observation and experience, is far beyond that which thou gettest by precept; as the knowledge of a traveler exceeds that which is got by reading.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: O how quickly passes away the glory of the earth.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: And when he is out of sight, quickly also is he out of mind.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What thou art, that thou art.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: All is vanity but to love and serve Him.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He who loves with purity considers not the gift of the lover, but the love of the giver.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Love feels no burden, regards not labors, strives toward more than it attains, argues not of impossibility, since it believes that it may and can do all things. Therefore it avails for all things, and fulfils and accomplishes much where one not a lover falls and lies helpless.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Love is swift, sincere, pious, pleasant, gentle, strong, patient, faithful, prudent, long-suffering, manly and never seeking her own; for whosoever a man seeketh his own, there he falleth from love.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Love alone makes heavy burdens light and bears in equal balance things pleasing and displeasing. Love bears a heavy burden and does not feel it, and love makes bitter things tasteful and sweet.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: It is much safer to obey than to rule.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: No one doth safely rule but he that hath learned gladly to obey.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: No man ruleth safely but that he is willingly ruled.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The only safe ruler is he who has learned to obey willingly.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He that seeketh anything else but simply God and the salvation of his soul, will find nothing but trouble and sorrow.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: At the least bear patiently, if thou canst not joyfully.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Set not thyself to attain much rest, but much patience.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Endeavor to be always patient of the faults and imperfections of others; for thou hast many faults and imperfections of thine own that require forbearance. If thou art not able to make thyself that which thou wishest, how canst thou expect to mold another in conformity to thy will?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: All men commend patience, although few are willing to practice it.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: It thou seek rest in this life, how wilt thou then attain to the everlasting rest? Dispose not thyself for much rest, but for great patience. Seek true peace - not in earth, but in heaven; not in men, nor in any other creature, but in God alone.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Let not your peace rest in the utterances of men, for whether they put a good or bad construction on your conduct does not make you other than you are.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Thou wilt enjoy tranquillity if thy heart condemn thee not.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Thy peace shall be in much patience.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: We should have much more peace if we would not busy ourselves with the sayings and doings of others.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Do not let your peace depend on the hearts of men; whatever they say about you, good or bad, you are not because of it another man, for as you are, you are.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Caution is crediting, and reserve in speaking, and in revealing one's self to but very few, are the best securities both of a good understanding with the world, and of the inward peace of our own minds.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: First keep peace with yourself, then you can also bring peace to others.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: A wise and good man will turn examples of all sorts to his own advantage. The good he will make his patterns, and strive to equal or excel them. The bad he will by all means avoid.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The loftier the building, the deeper must the foundation be laid.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: What most of all hinders heavenly consolation is that you are too slow in turning yourself to prayer.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: I would far rather feel remorse than know how to define it.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Constantly choose rather to want less, than to have more.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: A man is hindered and distracted in proportion as he draws outward things to himself.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Let this be thy whole endeavour, this thy prayer, this thy desire, that thou mayest be stripped of all selfishness, and with entire simplicity follow Jesus only.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Why seekest thou rest, since thou art born to labor?
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If you cast away one cross, you will certainly find another, and perhaps a heavier.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He that well and rightly considereth his own works will find little cause to judge hardly of another.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: But because many endeavor to get knowledge rather than to live well, they are often deceived and reap little or no benefit from their labor.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Man sees your actions, but God your motives.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Every man naturally desires knowledge; but what good is knowledge without fear of God? Indeed a humble rustic who serves God is better than a proud intellectual who neglects his soul to study the course of the stars.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: He that avoideth not small faults, by little and little falleth into greater.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: It is better to be affected with a true penitent sorrow for sin than to be able to resolve the most difficult cases about it.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Carry the cross patiently, and with perfect submission; and in the end it shall carry you.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: If you bear the cross unwillingly, you make it a burden, and load yourself more heavily; but you must bear it.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: We usually know what we can do, but temptation shows us who we are.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: There is no man in this world without some manner of tribulation or anguish, though he be king or pope.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: A lover of Jesus and of the truth can lift himself above himself in spirit.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: Influence never dies; every act, emotion, look and word makes influence tell for good or evil, happiness or woe, through the long future of eternity.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The highest and most profitable learning is the knowledge of ourselves. To have a low opinion of our own merits, and to think highly of others, is an evidence of wisdom.
author: Thomas a Kempis

quote: The ambitious climbs up high and perilous stairs, and never cares how to come down; the desire of rising hath swallowed up his fear of a fall.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Contention is like fire, for both burn so long as there is any exhaustible matter to contend within. Only herein it transcends fire, for fire begets not matter, but consumes it; debates beget matter, but consume it not.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: A man may be so bold of his predestination, that he forget his conversation.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: 'Baptizing them in the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.' The Father, Son, and Holy Ghost: there are three distinct persons: in the Name, not names; there is one essence.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Passion costs me too much to bestow it on every trifle.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Conscience is God's deputy in the soul.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Death is as near to the young as to the old; here is all the difference: death stands behind the young man's back, before the old man's face.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: We spend our years with sighing; it is a valley of tears; but death is the funeral of all our sorrows.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Alas! that the farthest and of all our thoughts should be the thought of our ends.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Both in thy private sessions, and the universal assizes, thou shalt be sure of the same Judge, the same jury, the same witnesses, the same verdict. How certain thou art to die, thou knowest; how soon to die, thou knowest not. Measure not thy life with the longest; that were to piece it out with flattery. Thou canst name no living man, not the sickest, which thou art sure shall die before thee.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: A drunkard is the annoyance of modesty; the trouble of civility; the spoil of wealth; the distraction of reason. He is the brewer's agent; the tavern and ale house benefactor; the beggar's companion; the constable's trouble; his wife's woe; his children's sorrow; his neighbor's scoff; his own shame. In short he is a tub of swill, a spirit of unrest, a thing below a beast, and a monster of a man.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: It was well done of Paul to reprove Peter to his face, and it was well done of Peter, to praise Paul in his absence.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: It is the office of faith to believe what we do not see, and it shall be the reward of faith to see what we do believe.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Our heavenly King is pleased with all our graces: hot zeal and cool patience pleaseth Him; cheerful thankfulness and weeping repentance pleaseth Him; but none of them are welcome to Him without faith, as nothing can please Him without Christ.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Sins are so remitted, as if they had never been committed.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: He who sends the storm steers the vessel.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Good deeds are such things that no man is saved for them, nor without them.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Grace comes into the soul, as the morning sun into the world; first a dawning; then a light; and at last the sun in his full and excellent brightness.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Let us be sure that our delights exclude not the presence of God: we may please ourselves so long as we do not displease Him.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: In spiritual graces let us study to be great, and not to know it.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: He that will be knighted must kneel for it, and he that will enter in at the strait gate must crowd for it--a gate made so on purpose, narrow and hard in the entrance, yet, after we have entered, wide and glorious, that after our pain our joy may be the sweeter.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: He who reforms himself, has done much toward reforming others; and one reason why the world is not reformed, is, because each would have others make a beginning, and never thinks of himself doing it.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The hypocrite, certainly, is a secret atheist; for if he did believe there was a God, he durst not be so bold as to deceive Him to His face.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Ahab cast a covetous eye at Naboth's vineyard, David a lustful eye at Bathsheba. The eye is the pulse of the soul; as physicians judge of the heart by the pulse, so we by the eye; a rolling eye, a roving heart. The good eye keeps minute time, and strikes when it should; the lustful, crochet-time, and so puts all out of tune.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The covetous man is like a camel with a great hunch on his back; heaven's gate must be made Higher and broader, or he will hardly get in.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The covetous man pines in plenty, like Tantalus up to the chin in water, and yet thirsty.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Beauty is like an almanack: if it lasts a year it is well.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: As God by creation made two of one, so again by marriage He made one of two.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: No man more truly loves God than he that is most fearful to offend Him.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: True obedience hath no lead at its heels.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The patient man is merry indeed.... The jailers that watch him are but his pages of honour, and his very dungeon but the lower side of the vault of heaven. He kisseth the wheel that must kill him; and thinks the stairs of the scaffold of his martyrdom but so many degrees of his ascent to glory. The tormentors are weary of him. the beholders have pitty on him, all men wonder at him; and while he seems below all men, below himself, he is above nature. He hath so overcome hlmself that nothing can conquer him.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Even the tired horse, when he comes near home, mends pace: be good always, without weariness, but best at last; that the nearer thou comest to the end of thy days, the nearer thou mayest be to the end of thy hopes, the salvation of thy soul.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Blessed be God, I not only begin praying when I kneel down, but I do not leave off praying when I rise up.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Pride thrust Nebuchadnezzar out of men's society, Saul out of his kingdom, Adam out of paradise, Haman out of court, and Lucifer out of heaven.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Self-righteousness is the devil's masterpiece to make us think well of ourselves.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: That which a man spits against heaven, shall fall back on his own face.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The devil is no idle spirit, but a vagrant, runagate walker, that never rests in one place. The motive, cause, and main intention of his walking is to ruin man.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Satan, like a fisher, baits his hook according to the appetite of the fish.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The Word of life may be so distorted from the life of the Word till it becomes the food of death.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Sense of sin may be often great, and more felt than grace; yet not be more than grace. A man feels the ache of his finger more sensibly than the health of his whole body; yet he knows that the ache of a finger is nothing so much as the health of the whole body.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The Bible is to us what the star was to the wise men; but if we spend all our time in gazing upon it, observing its motions, and admiring its splendor, without being led to Christ by it, the use of it will be lost to us.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: It is rashness to search, godliness to believe, safeness to preach, and eternal blessedness to know the Trinity.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: Half our virtue arises from our being out of the way of temptation.
author: Thomas Adams

quote: The test of the artist does not lie in the will with which he goes to work, but in the excellence of the work he produces.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: If the highest aim of a captain were to preserve his ship, he would keep it in port forever.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Beware of the person of one book.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Man cannot live without joy; therefore when he is deprived of true spiritual joys it is necessary that he become addicted to carnal pleasures.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Whatever is received is received according to the nature of the recipient.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: If, then, you are looking for the way by which you should go, take Christ, because He Himself is the way.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: I would rather feel compassion than know the meaning of it.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: To convert somebody go and take them by the hand and guide them.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: The principal act of courage is to endure and withstand dangers doggedly rather than to attack them.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Temperance is simply a disposition of the mind which binds the passions.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Wonder is the desire for knowledge.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: To teach in order to lead others to faith is the task of every preacher and of each believer.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: To one who has faith, no explanation is necessary. To one without faith, no explanation is possible.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Faith has to do with things that are not seen and hope with things that are not at hand.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Hold firmly that our faith is identical with that of the ancients. Deny this, and you dissolve the unity of the Church.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: We can't have full knowledge all at once. We must start by believing; then afterwards we may be led on to master the evidence for ourselves.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Faith is God's work within us.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Far graver is it to corrupt the faith that is the life of the soul than to counterfeit the money that sustains temporal life.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: When fear is excessive it can make many a man despair.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Friendship is the source of the greatest pleasures, and without friends even the most agreeable pursuits become tedious.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Moral science is better occupied when treating of friendship than of justice.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: There is nothing on this earth more to be prized than true friendship.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Man should not consider his material possession his own, but as common to all, so as to share them without hesitation when others are in need.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: How can we live in harmony? First we need to know we are all madly in love with the same God.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: It is possible to demonstrate God's existence, although not a priori, yet a posteriori from some work of His more surely known to us.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Good can exist without evil, whereas evil cannot exist without good.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: How is it they live in such harmony the billions of stars - when most men can barely go a minute without declaring war in their minds about someone they know.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Law; an ordinance of reason for the common good, made by him who has care of the community.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: There is within every soul a thirst for happiness and meaning.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Happiness is secured through virtue; it is a good attained by man's own will.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: God destines us for an end beyond the grasp of reason.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: That the saints may enjoy their beatitude and the grace of God more abundantly they are permitted to see the punishment of the damned in hell.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Clearly the person who accepts the Church as an infallible guide will believe whatever the Church teaches.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: If forgers and malefactors are put to death by the secular power, there is much more reason for excommunicating and even putting to death one convicted of heresy.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Justice is a certain rectitude of mind whereby a man does what he ought to do in the circumstances confronting him.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: By nature all men are equal in liberty, but not in other endowments.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Sorrow can be alleviated by good sleep, a bath and a glass of wine.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: The highest manifestation of life consists in this: that a being governs its own actions. A thing which is always subject to the direction of another is somewhat of a dead thing.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Love takes up where knowledge leaves off.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: The things that we love tell us what we are.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: For loving draws us more to things than knowing does, since good is found by going to the thing, whereas the true is found when the thing comes to us.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: To bear with patience wrongs done to oneself is a mark of perfection, but to bear with patience wrongs done to someone else is a mark of imperfection and even of actual sin.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Because philosophy arises from awe, a philosopher is bound in his way to be a lover of myths and poetic fables. Poets and philosophers are alike in being big with wonder.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: It is clear that he does not pray, who, far from uplifting himself to God, requires that God shall lower Himself to him, and who resorts to prayer not to stir the man in us to will what God wills, but only to persuade God to will what the man in us wills.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: A man has free choice to the extent that he is rational.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: All the efforts of the human mind cannot exhaust the essence of a single fly.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: It is requisite for the relaxation of the mind that we make use, from time to time, of playful deeds and jokes.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Most men seem to live according to sense rather than reason.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Reason in man is rather like God in the world.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Human salvation demands the divine disclosure of truths surpassing reason.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: There is but one Church in which men find salvation, just as outside the ark of Noah it was not possible for anyone to be saved.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Three things are necessary for the salvation of man: to know what he ought to believe; to know what he ought to desire; and to know what he ought to do.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: To live well is to work well, to show a good activity.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: As a matter of honor, one man owes it to another to manifest the truth.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: All that is true, by whomsoever it has been said has its origin in the Spirit.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Better to illuminate than merely to shine, to deliver to others contemplated truths than merely to contemplate.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Because of the diverse conditions of humans, it happens that some acts are virtuous to some people, as appropriate and suitable to them, while the same acts are immoral for others, as inappropriate to them.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Perfection of moral virtue does not wholly take away the passions, but regulates them.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: In order for a war to be just, three things are necessary. First, the authority of the sovereign. Secondly, a just cause. Thirdly, a rightful intention.
author: Thomas Aquinas

quote: Affliction doth not rise out of the dust or come to men by chance; but it is the Lord that sends it, and we should own and reverence His hand in it.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: Whoever be the instruments of any good to us, of whatever sort, we must look above them, and eye the hand and counsel of God in it, which is the first spring, and be duly thankful to God for it. And whatever evil of crosses or afflictions befalls us, we must look above the instruments of it to God.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: God hath decreed the end, so He hath decreed the means that are proper for attaining that end; so that these two must not be separated.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: Has God decreed all things that come to pass? Then there is nothing that falls out by chance, nor are we to ascribe what we meet with either to good or ill luck and fortune. There are many events in the world which men look upon as mere accidents, yet all these come by the counsel and appointment of Heaven.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: Consider the end of God's decrees - and this is no other than His own glory. Every rational agent acts for an end; and God being the most perfect agent, and His glory the highest end, there can be no doubt but all His decrees are directed to that end. 'For to Him are all things' (Rom. 11.36).
author: Thomas Boston

quote: It is our duty to look to God's commands, and not to His decrees; to our own duty, and not to His purposes. The decrees of God are a vast ocean, into which many possibly have curiously pried to their own horror and despair; but few or none have ever pried into them to their own profit and satisfaction.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: They that would keep themselves pure must have their bodies in subjection, and that may require, in some cases, a holy violence.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: Again, the glory of one attribute is more seen in one work than in another: in some things there is more of His goodness, in other things more of His wisdom is seen, and in others more of His power. But in the work of redemption all His perfections and excellencies shine forth in their greatest glory.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: A righteous man may make a righteous work, but no work of an unrighteous man can make him righteous. Now we become righteous only by faith, through the righteousness of Christ imputed to us.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: A man shall as soon force fruit out of a branch broken off from the tree and withered, as work righteousness without believing in, and uniting with Christ. These are two things by which those that hear the gospel are ruined.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: It is great folly to cast your sins upon Satan who tempted you, or upon your neighbor who provoked you; but it is a far greater sin, nay horrid blasphemy, to cast it upon God Himself. A greater affront than this cannot be offered to the infinite holiness of God.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: For as the sun darts its beams upon a dunghill, and yet is no way defiled by it; so God decrees the permission of sin... yet is not the author of sin.
author: Thomas Boston

quote: Afflictions are but as a dark entry into our Father's house.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Those years, months, weeks, days, and hours, that are not filled up with God, with Christ, with grace, and with duty, will certainly be filled up with vanity and folly. The neglect of one day, of one duty, of one hour, would undo us, if we had not an Advocate with the Father.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Our sins are debts that none can pay but Christ. It is not our tears, but His blood; it is not our sighs, but His sufferings, that can testify for our sins. Christ must pay all, or we are prisoners forever.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Christ is the sun, and all the watches of our lives should be set by the dial of his motion.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: The two poles could sooner meet, than the love of Christ and the love of the world.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: A good conscience and a good confidence go together.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: It is better to have a sore than a seared conscience.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Much faith will yield unto us here our heaven, but any faith, if true, will yield us heaven hereafter.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Though there is nothing more dangerous, yet there is nothing more ordinary, than for weak saints to make their sense and feeling the judge of their condition. We must strive to walk by faith.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Weak Christians are afraid of the shadow of the cross.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: A man had need to fear this most of all, that he fears not at all.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: You had better be a poor man and a rich Christian, than a rich man and a poor Christian. You had better do anything, bear anything, and be anything rather than be a dwarf in grace.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Let those be thy choicest companions who have made Christ their chief companion.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: It is not he who knows most, nor he who hears most, nor yet he who talks most, but he who exercises grace most, who has most communion with God.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: It is the very nature of grace to make a man strive to be most eminent in that particular grace which is most opposed to his bosom sin.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: There is no such way to attain to greater measures of grace, as for a man to live up to that little grace he has.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: As heat is opposed to cold, and light to darkness, so grace is opposed to sin. Fire and water may as well agree in the same vessel, as grace and sin in the same heart.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: You may as soon fill a bag with wisdom, a chest with virtue, or a circle with a triangle, as the heart of man with anything here below. A man may have enough of the world to sink him, but he can never have enough to satisfy him.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Faith is the champion of grace, and love the nurse; but humility is the beauty of grace.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: God hears no more than the heart speaks; and if the heart be dumb, God will certainly be deaf.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: 'My sin is ever before me' [Psalm 51.3]. A humble soul sees that he can stay no more from sin, than the heart can from panting, and the pulse from beating. He sees his heart and life to be fuller of sin, than the firmament is of stars; and this keeps him low. He sees that sin is so bred in the bone, that till his bones, as Joseph's, be carried out of the Egypt of this world, it will not out. Though sin and grace were never born together, and though they shall not die together, yet while the believer lives, these two must live together; and this keeps him humble.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: How many threadbare souls are to be found under silken cloaks and gowns!
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: An idle life and a holy heart is a contradiction.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Oh, is the Lord Jesus Christ a believer's life? Why, then, let no believer be disquieted, nor overwhelmed and dejected, for any loss or for any sorrow or suffering that he meets with for the Lord Jesus Christ's sake. Oh, what should a man then do for Jesus Christ, who is his life!
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: We trust as we love, and where we love. If we love Christ much, surely we shall trust him much.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: He that hath deserved hanging may be glad to escape with a whipping.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Nothing humbles and breaks the heart of a sinner like mercy and love. Souls that converse much with sin and wrath, may be much terrified; but souls that converse much with grace and mercy, will be much humbled.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Cold prayers shall never have any warm answers. God will suit His returns to our requests. Lifeless, services shall have lifeless answers. When men are dull, God will be dumb.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: The best and sweetest flowers of paradise God gives to His people when they are upon their knees. Prayer is the gate of heaven.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Prayer crowns God with the honor and glory due to His name, and God crowns prayer with assurance and comfort. The most praying souls are the most assured souls.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Look, as a painted man is no man, and as painted fire is no fire, so a cold prayer is no prayer.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: God looks not at the oratory of your prayers, how elegant they may be; nor at the geometry of your prayers, how long they may be; nor at the arithmetic of your prayers, how many they may be; not at logic of your prayers, how methodical they may be; but the sincerity of them he looks at.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Christ choosing solitude for private prayer, doth not only hint to us the danger of distraction and deviation of thoughts in prayer, but how necessary it is for us to choose the most convenient places we can for private prayer. Our own fickleness and Satan's restlessness call upon us to get into such places where we may freely pour out our soul into the bosom of God [Mark 1.35].
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: God sees us in secret, therefore, let, us seek his face in secret. Though heaven be God's palace, yet it is not his prison.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: God's hearing of our prayers doth not depend upon sanctification, but upon Christ's intercession; not upon what we are in ourselves, but what' we are in the Lord Jesus; both our persons and our prayers are acceptable in the beloved [Eph 1.6].
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Prayer is nothing but the breathing that out before the Lord, that was first breathed into us by the Spirit of the Lord.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: The lives of ministers oftentimes convince more strongly than their words; their tongues may persuade, but their lives command.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Ambition is a gilded misery, a secret poison, a hidden plague, the engineer of deceit, the mother of hypocrisy, the parent of envy, the original of vices, the moth of holiness, the blinder of hearts, turning medicines into maladies, and remedies into diseases.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Secret sins commonly lie nearest the heart.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Repentance is a grace, and must have its daily operation, as well as other graces. A true penitent must go on from faith to faith, from strength to strength; he must never stand still or turn back. True repentance is a continued spring, where the waters of godly sorrow are always flowing. 'My sin is ever before me'.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: A man's most glorious actions will at last be found to be but glorious sins, if he hath made himself, and not the glory of God, the end of those actions.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Deliver me, O Lord, from that evil man, myself.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: The best way to do ourselves good is to be doing good to others; the best way to gather is to scatter.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: There is the seed of all sins - of the vilest and worst of sins - in the best of men.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: He who stands upon his own strength will never stand.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Suffering times are sealing times. The primitive Christians found them so, and the suffering saints in Mary's days found them so. When the furnace is seven times hotter than ordinary, the Spirit of the Lord comes and seals up a man's pardon in his bosom, his peace with God, and his title to heaven. Blessed Bradford looked upon his sufferings as an evidence to him that he was on the right way to heaven.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: When you have overcome one temptation, you must be ready to enter the lists with another. As distrust, in some sense, is the mother of safety, so security is the gate of danger.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: The only way to avoid cannon-shot is to fall down. No such way to be freed from temptation as to keep low.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Truth is mighty and will prevail.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: Where truth goes, I will go, and where truth is I will be, and nothing but death shall divide me and the truth.
author: Thomas Brooks

quote: For a hundred that can bear adversity there is hardly one that can bear prosperity.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Blessed is he who has found his work; let him ask no other blessedness. He has a work, a life-purpose; he has found it, and will follow it! Labor is life.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: If time is precious, no book that will not improve by repeated readings deserves to be read at all.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Good Christian people, here lies for you an inestimable loan; take all heed thereof, in all carefulness, employ it: with high recompense, or else with heavy penalty, will it one day be required back.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Show me the person you honor, for I know better by that the kind of person you are. For you show me what your idea of humanity is.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Men's hearts ought not to be set against one another, but set with one another, and all against evil only.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: The eternal stars shine out as soon as it is dark enough.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: No iron chain, or outward force of any kind, could ever compel the soul of man to believe or to disbelieve: it is his own indefeasible light, that judgment of his; he will reign and believe there by the grace of God alone!
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: What is nature? Art thou not the living government of God? O Heaven, is it in very deed He then that ever speaks through thee, that lives and loves in thee, that lives and loves in me?
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: A man cannot make a pair of shoes rightly unless he do it in a devout manner.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Piety does not mean that a man should make a sour face about things, and refuse to enjoy in moderation what his Maker has given.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: In idleness there is a perpetual despair.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: He walked into Judaea eighteen hundred years ago; His sphere melody, flowing in wild native tones, took captive the ravished souls of men, and, being of a truth sphere melody, still flows and sounds, though now with thousandfold accompaniments and rich symphonies, through all our hearts, and modulates and divinely leads them.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: We are the miracle of miracles, the great inscrutable mystery of God.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Intellect is the soul of man, the only immortal part of him.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: A man's religion consists, not of the many things he is in doubt of and tries to believe, but of the few he is assured of and has no need of effort for believing.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: The devil has his elect.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Sarcasm I now see to be, in general, the language of the devil; for which reason I have long since as good as renounced it.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: All men, if they work not as in the great taskmaster's eye, will work wrong, and work unhappily for themselves and for you.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Labor is life: from the inmost heart of the worker rises his God-given force, the sacred celestial life-essence breathed into him by Almighty God!
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Blessed be the God's voice; for it is true, and falsehoods have to cease before it!
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: Care and diligence bring luck.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Good is not good, where better is expected.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Prospect is often better than possession.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The great end of life is not knowledge, but action.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Anger is short-lived in a good man.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Anger is one of the sinews of the soul. He who wants it hath a maimed mind.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The weakest and most timorous are the most revengeful and implacable.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Two things a man should never be angry at: what he can help, and what he cannot help.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Remember. O my soul, the fig tree was charged, not with bearing noxious fruit, but no fruit.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Haste and rashness are storms and tempests, breaking and wrecking business; but nimbleness is a full fair wind blowing it with speed to the haven.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: One cloud is enough to eclipse all the sun.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He that knows nothing will believe anything.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: An index is a necessary implement, without which a large author is but a labyrinth without a clue to direct the readers within.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A book that is shut is but a block.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Learning hath gained most by those books by which the printers have lost.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Take heed of jesting; many have been ruined by it. It is hard to jest, and not sometimes jeer too, which often sinks deeper than we intended or expected.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It is good to make a jest, but not to make a trade of jesting.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Make no vows to perform this or that; it shows no great strength, and makes thee ride behind thyself.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: There are heads sometimes so little, that there is no room for wit, sometimes so long that there is no wit for so much room.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A man is not good or bad for one action.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A man surprised is half beaten.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Better be alone than in bad company.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Every tub must stand on its own bottom.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Fame sometimes hath created something of nothing.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Great and good are seldom the same man.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If an ass goes traveling he will not come home a horse.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It is the glory of the true religion that it inculcates and inspires a spirit of benevolence. It is a religion of charity, which none other ever was. Christ went about doing good; he set the example to his disciples, and they abounded in it.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Good counsels observed, are chains to grace, which, neglected, prove halters to strange, undutiful children.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Disobedient children, if preserved from the gallows, are reserved for the rack, to be tortured by their own posterity. One complaining, that never father had so undutiful a child as he had, yes, said his son, with less grace than truth, my grandfather had.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Let thy child's first lesson be obedience, and the second may be what thou wilt.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It is a shame when the church itself is a cemetery, where the living sleep above the ground, as the dead do beneath.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Many come to bring their clothes to church rather than themselves.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A wounded conscience is able to unparadise paradise itself.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: One that will not plead that cause wherein his tongue must be confuted by his conscience.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Venture not to the utmost bounds of even lawful pleasures; the limits of good and evil join.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If the wicked flourish, and thou suffer, be not discouraged; they are fatted for destruction, thou art dieted for health.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Thou must content thyself to see the world imperfect as it is. Thou wilt never have any quiet if thou vexest thyself because thou canst not bring mankind to that exact notion of things and rule of life which thou hast formed in thy own mind.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Contentment consist not in adding more fuel, but in taking away some fire.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: I will not meddle with that which I cannot mend.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If you run after two hares, you will catch neither.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The Golden Age was never the present Age.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: What cannot be altered must be borne, not blamed.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Despair gives courage to a coward.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The more wit the less courage.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: We could be cowards, if we had courage enough.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The number of malefactors authorizes not the crime.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: No man who is fit to live need fear to die. To us here, death is the most terrible thing we know. But when we have tasted its reality it will mean to us birth, deliverance, a new creation of ourselves. It will be what health is to the sick man; what home is to the exile; what the loved one given back is to the bereaved. As we draw near to it a solemn gladness should fill our hearts. It is God's great morning lighting up the sky. Our fears are the terror of children in the night. The night with its terrors, its darkness, its feverish dreams, is passing away; and when we awake it will be into the sunlight of God.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Tombs are the clothes of the dead; a grave is but a plain suit; a rich monument is an embroidered one.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He that will not sail till all dangers are over must never put to sea.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Scalded cats fear even cold water.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Curiosity is a kernel of the forbidden fruit which still sticketh in the throat of a natural man, sometimes to the danger of his choking.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If thou art a master, be sometimes blind, if a servant, sometimes deaf.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Rashness is the faithful but unhappy parent of misfortune.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If the master takes no account of his servants, they will make small account of him, and care not what they spend, who are never brought to an audit.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Bad excuses are worse than none.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Better a little fire to warm us than a great one to burn us.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Better fare hard with good men than feast with bad.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Choose a wife rather by your ear than your eye.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Do not in an instant what an age cannot recompense.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: One may miss the mark by aiming too high, as too low.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Soft words are hard arguments.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Tis skill, not strength, that governs a ship.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Trust thyself only, and another shall not betray thee.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: With foxes we must play the fox.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A drinker has a hole under his nose that all his money runs into.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Wine hath drowned more men than the sea.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Old foxes want no tutors.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If thou wouldst please the ladies, thou must endeavor to make them pleased with themselves.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Compliments cost nothing, yet many pay dear for them.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: 'Tis better that thou be rather something sparing, than very liberal, to even a good servant; for as he grows full, he inclines either to be idle, or to leave thee: and if he should at any time murmur, thou mayest govern him by a seasonable reward.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A good schoolmaster minces his precepts for children to swallow, hanging clogs on the nimbleness of his own soul, that his scholars may go along with him.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He that has no fools, knaves nor beggars in his family was begot by a flash of lightning.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Jars concealed are half reconciled; but if generally known, it is a double task to stop the breach at home and men's mouths abroad.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A man's best fortune, or his worst, is his wife.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Better one's house be too little one day than too big all the year after.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Charity begins at home, but should not end there.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: First get an absolute conquest over thyself, and then thou wilt easily govern thy wife.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He knows little, who will tell his wife all he knows.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: My son is my son till he have got him a wife, But my daughter's my daughter all the days of her life.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A coward's fear can make a coward valiant.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Cruelty is a tyrant that's always attended with fear.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He that fears not the future may enjoy the present.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It is riches of the mind only that make a man rich and happy.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It is much better to have your gold in the hand than in the heart.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Reward a good servant well, and rather get quit of a bad one than disquiet thyself with him.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: There is a Spanish proverb, that one who would grow rich must buy of those who go to be executed, as not caring how cheap they sell; and sell to those who go to be married, as not caring how dear they buy.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Better give a shilling than lend and lose half a crown.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He is poor indeed that can promise nothing.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He is rich that is satisfied.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Riches enlarge, rather than satisfy appetites.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: The pleasures of the rich are bought with the tears of the poor.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Some men, like a tiled house, are long before they take fire, but once on flame there is no coming near to quench them.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Forgetting of a wrong is a mild revenge.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He that cannot forgive others breaks the bridge over which he must pass himself; for every man has need to be forgiven.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: No man can be happy without a friend, nor be sure of his friend till he is unhappy.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: God send me a friend that will tell me of my faults.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: It the best to be with those in time, that we hope to be with in eternity.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Make not thy friends too cheap to thee, nor thyself to thy friend.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If thou would'st be borne with, then bear with others.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Let friendship creep gently to a height; if it rushes to it, it may soon run itself out of breath.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Make not a bosom friend of a melancholy soul: he'll be sure to aggravate thy adversity, and lessen thy prosperity. He goes always heavy loaded; and thou must bear half. He's never in a good humor; and may easily get into a bad one, and fall out with thee.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: A good friend is my nearest relation.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Be a friend to thyself, and others will be so too.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Friendship that flames goes out in a flash.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: He's my friend that speaks well of me behind my back.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: If you have one true friend you have more than your share.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: There is a scarcity of friendship, but not of friends.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: They are rich who have true friends.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: We can live without our friends but not without our neighbors.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: We shall never have friends if we expect to find them without fault.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: As the sword of the best tempered metal is most flexible, so the truly generous are most pliant and courteous in their behavior to their inferiors.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Generosity, wrong placed, becometh a vice; a princely mind will undo a private family.
author: Thomas Fuller
